urn:contentItem:5VMV-PR61-JB20-G3J5-00000-00Bomb Cyclone Forces Nearly 3,100 Flight Cancellations As Major Storm Moves Across U.S. Facebook's Data Deals Are Under Criminal Investigation; Rep. Greg Walden (R), Oregon is Interviewed About the Green New Deal; Tesla Announcing New Chief Financial and Chief Accounting Officer; FAA Grounds 737 Max 8; College Cheating Scam2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:30ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, David Bruno, Greg Walden, Dion Rabouin, Robin BiroNEWSFinancial031403cb.231Bomb Cyclone Forces Nearly 3,100 Flight Cancellations As Major Storm Moves Across U.S. Facebook's Data Deals Are Under Criminal Investigation; Rep. Greg Walden (R), Oregon is Interviewed About the Green New Deal; Tesla Announcing New Chief Financial and Chief Accounting Officer; FAA Grounds 737 Max 8; College Cheating ScamMaria Bartiromo, Morgan Ortagus, Dagen McDowell, Jeff Flock, Karl Rove, Cheryl Casone; Gerri Willis, Dani Klupenger, Stuart Varney, Kat Timpf

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Thursday, March 14th. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Grounded. President Trump has announced that he's keeping all Boeing 737 Max jets in the U.S. parked as new reports say the Ethiopian Airlines crash show similarity to last year's Lion Air accident.

Facebook reportedly facing a criminal investigation. At the center of that probe, the social media giant's data deals with technology companies. It comes after a major outage hits Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp yesterday.

Markets are lower this morning. Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading, down 26 points on the Dow. That's well off of the lows of the morning. The S&P is down two and the NASDAQ is now slipped into positive territory, it is up four points. This after a wild day yesterday on Wall Street when all was set and done the major indices finished strong up 148 points on the Dow industrials yesterday, two-thirds of one percent.

The S&P was up 19, the NASDAQ was up 52. Two-thirds of a percent there as well. In Europe this morning, markets are higher across the board. FT-100 up 48, CAC Quarante up 35, DAX Index up 21. In Asia overnight, mixed performance. Worst performer was China. Shanghai Composite down 1-1/4 percent.

A deadly and historic blizzard bringing hurricane force winds to central U.S. And those winds causing this tractor trailer to completely flip over in Texas.

Out on bond. Actress Lori Loughlin posting a million after appearing in court for her alleged role in the college admissions scandal.

Plus, pay to play. A new report says electronic arts paid top gamer ninja a million dollars to promote Apex legends. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Forbes Media chairman, former Republican Presidential Candidate Steve Forbes, and national security analyst, Fox News Contributor Morgan Ortagus. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you.

FORBES: Lot of news, especially on the college front. This big overhang is still China. Where we get that trade deal.

BARTIROMO: I know. We haven't heard when this meeting is between President Trump and Xi Jinping. Now the President says they're pushing it off until April.

FORBES: And you have to wonder, does this mean they're close to a deal but they're trying to get last-minute concessions and they're planning to seek --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Or not close at all.

ORTAGUS: I think you hit the nail on the head earlier, Steve. It's all about enforcement, right? What is he going to -- we talked about this on the show just a few weeks ago. What is Xi going to say to Trump that he didn't already promise in 2015 in the Rose Garden with President Obama? How do we hold their feet to the fire? How do we enforce these things? That's what's crucial for me for this deal.

BARTIROMO: Right. And the U.S. wants to be able to put tariffs back in place, should the Chinese not follow through on their promises. The Chinese say well, then we want that as well.

FORBES: Yes. The Chinese are never going to agree to that. But the key thing is not just the enforcement mechanism. It's the ability or the willingness of the United States to enforce agreements. We haven't done it consistently in the past. That's why this Huawei thing is so important. We are now going to do it in the future. I think that weighs more than any mechanism.

ORTAGUS: Absolutely. Absolutely.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And I will quickly point to a great, what they call in journalism, a tick-tock in the Wall Street Journal about this college cheating scandal. And it all started with one guy, a financial executive who was being pursued on securities fraud charges and he told investigators, oh, I got something much bigger for you. And he pointed to the Yale Soccer coach wore a wire, meeting with him in Boston, who asked the individual, this coach asked for a $450,000 payout to get a kid into Yale and there, the ball started rolling.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: It was surveillance, phones being tapped of the mastermind, Rick Singer. He was recording conversations. He tried to tip off about half a dozen of the families that he was wearing a wire and that they ought to be careful but again, 33 parents charged so far. Lori Loughlin out on -- a million dollars bail is a huge amount of money.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So he was trying to get his securities issues lessened. He was under securities investigation and that's how he did it. By saying look over here.

MCDOWELL: People with money can be very, very stupid.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Meanwhile, the U.S. is grounding the entire Boeing 737 Max fleet after the deadly crash in Ethiopia. Jeff flock is covering the story. He's live at O'Hare International Airport this morning in Chicago. Jeff, good morning to you.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning. One- two punch to air travelers today. Both the storm canceling flights as well as the grounding of those aircraft, the 737 Maxes. Take a look at the board at O'Hare. If you see yellow or red, that means your flight is either canceled or delayed. The grounding of the 737s announced by the President yesterday. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The safety of the American people and all people is our paramount concern. All of those planes are grounded effective immediately.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FLOCK: Latest on the investigation, one, the black box now to France to be analyzed but as you reported earlier, Maria, similarities in the two crashes. That leading the FAA to say we better shut it all down. People being rebooked now but as we said, some of the flights canceled. Now, as you reported also, a fairly small number of planes in the air that are 737 Maxes or at least were in the air. Southwest, the biggest among them.

But if you look at the overall fleet, take a look at those numbers, the overall U.S. Air fleet is about 7,000 or more aircraft. The number grounded, less than 70. You can do the math on that. It's less than one percent. We have the latest number of delays and cancellations and I would say the Lion's share of these are as a result of the so-called bomb cyclone. Don't like that term, but there you go.

490 delays and over 1,000 cancellations, the majority of those coming in Denver. Number two on the list here in Chicago. We're at least number two on the list. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right, Jeff, thanks very much. We'll keep following that. Jeff Flock in Chicago this morning. I want to turn to the race for 2020 now. Beto O'Rourke has thrown his hat in the ring officially for the Democratic nomination.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BETO O'ROURKE (D) TEXAS: This is a defining moment of truth for this country and for every single one of us. The challenges that we face right now, the interconnected crises in our economy, our democracy and our climate have never been greater.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the former senior adviser to President George W. Bush and Fox News Contributor, Karl Rove. Karl, great to see you.

KARL ROVE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. How are you, Maria?

BARTIROMO: I'm great. Want to get to your op-ed on AOC in a second. But first, your reaction to Beto announcing his bid.

ROVE: Am I the only one who thinks it's ironic that he sort of makes his announcement in a long interview in a magazine with vanity in its title?

(CROSSTALK)

ROVE: Look, it was revealing -- it was a revealing interview, though. He said you know what, I never prepare my speeches which is why he said he's a reckless guy as a result. So that's what led him to say I don't think there's nothing more American than taking a knee, law enforcement is the Jim -- new Jim Crow-ism. We heard him recently in El Paso say, yes, I'm in favor of tearing down all the fences and borders between us and Mexico.

It's why when he went out to campaign in Texas in 2017 and '18 and went to all 254 counties, he would go to these small towns and give a speech to the local group of Democrats and routinely drop the F-bomb. And that was OK, I guess, for the hip parts of Dallas and Austin and Houston, but when you're out in Friona or Jacksonville or Cuero, those people are church-going people even if they're Democrats and by god, you don't use the F-bomb in front of polite people. I mean, he's a little bit reckless.

FORBES: So what's the attraction, Karl? Other than he's a pretty boy and nearly beat Ted Cruz, who had his own popularity issues in Texas? What's the fascination with this guy? Should we take him seriously?

ROVE: Well, -- Steve, glad you asked. I've got a white board here. Some -- for the interview as well. For the interview as well. You can't -- he said, you know, you can't hide from whom you are. And he's right. And he's got charisma and natural authenticity and a comfort level about being around people and being in the public arena and that will be helpful to him. He talks in the article about how he is more enthused about talking about what he is for than what he is against.

And I think it's going to be an important element in the 2020 campaign for any Democrat. He said I got to have a campaign that looks like America. He realizes that he's a white guy so he's going to have a campaign and pledges an administration that looks like America. So we're going to see a lot of -- a lot of women and we're going to see a lot of people of color in his campaign. He says, I will work with republicans. I did it when I was in Congress.

I will do it as President which is going to be unique. Is Elizabeth Warren going to say, Bernie Sanders going to say, Kamala Harris going to say, oh, I'm going to work with Republicans? And then remember, he raised $80 million for a Senate race. The question is how many of those donors are going to stick with him. But that's a big starting point that makes it -- makes it possible for him to be competitive. The real question's going to be what's the message?

BARTIROMO: Right.

ROVE: And we've got a little bit of a sense of it. It's like hope and optimism, we're a great country, we faced big challenges but we can overcome them. We'll see how this goes. The big challenge for him is going to be his Senate race where he got close to Ted Cruz is not going to be like the Presidential race because Ted Cruz ignored him. He gave him 2018 -- excuse me, 2017 and virtually all of 2018 to go out there and be by himself projecting a message to the voters and only in late September and October did Cruz engage with him.

BARTIROMO: Oh, really? OK.

ROVE: He's going to be engaged with right away by a bunch of Democrats. We'll see how he handles it.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Karl, it's Dagen McDowell.

ROVE: Dagen? Of course it is.

MCDOWELL: "Here's Beto O'Rourke," the challenges we face are the greatest in living memory. OK. Not the Great Depression, not Pearl Harbor, not World War II, not the Cold War, not the Cuban Missile Crisis, not the 70s with the Sky High guest, not 9/11, not the 2008 financial crisis. Down south we say don't spit in my face and tell me it's raining.

ROVE: Yes, yes. This is going to be a problem for all the Democrats of hyperventilating about how bad the country is but remember that helps them inside their party. There are -- there are -- the core of the Democratic base does believe the biggest threat we have faced in our lifetimes is the presence of Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office. This is I think Robert Francis O'Rourke's attempt to negotiate around this.

And look, please, let's not refer to him by the fake name -- nickname that he did not use at Woodbury Forest, that he did not use at Colombia, that he did not use as an adult when he was -- when he was in a grunge band but only started to reemphasize when he ran for the city council in a heavily Latino town, El Paso, Texas. Let's please refer to him by the name that he appears on the ballot as Robert Francis O'Rourke. Please. Let's do that.

MCDOWELL: Wait, wait, wait. He went to Woodbury? Well, that's an elitist private school in Orange, Virginia.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What's that about?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Right.

ROVE: Well, he was there -- he was there when it was not co-ed. So -- and he went to Colombia. As I remember, that's sort of a private elite institution on the upper west side of New York.

BARTIROMO: So he just started using it when he ran for office. That's interesting because I was just asking the panel about Beto and Robert Francis and why now we're calling him Beto. I mean, he's Irish, right?

ROVE: Well, he's Robert Francis O'Rourke. Yes. And look, if you want a want a nickname, let's give him what his name represents RFOR. Robert Francis O'Rourke. RFOR. Come on.

BARTIROMO: Karl, before you go, you got to talk to us about your op-ed this morning in the Journal. American history as told by AOC.

ROVE: Yes. I listened to her speech here in Austin at south by southwest and it is jaw-dropping. Look, of course, we were going to have her and the moderator immediately say Donald J. Trump is a racist but Ronald Reagan is a racist and why, because he talked about a woman who bilked welfare in the 70s out of $150,000 and he called her -- he didn't call her welfare queen. Others did.

But AOC says well, that was racist. Well, the woman was white. Please tell me what's racist about that. And then FDR --

BARTIROMO: How about the new deal? The new deal too.

ROVE: Yes. The new deal was racist because it expanded, it legit -- it literally gave mortgage relief to white people but not to black people and as a result, the housing gap, the wealth gap grew because of the racist policies of Franklin Roosevelt. Well, first of all, it is not borne out by the facts. The Home Owners' Loan Corporation did not expand the difference between home ownership between blacks and whites.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROVE: And it's just jaw-dropping.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And she said it does not -- it does not feel good to live in America today. I mean, what in the world are these people living in?

ROVE: Exactly. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: The America is the highlight of the world. I mean, particularly now, where you've got this economy that is -- that is firing on all cylinders.

FORBES: You know, we're raising money here to give her a ticket to Venezuela.

ROVE: Well, you know what, that private charity is wrong. The government should pay for the ticket to Venezuela. Please. Private charity is bad. It's -- that's merely an expression of the wealthy who have been stealing the money from -- what I loved was she was talking about ordinary people, ordinary working people and her audience had to pay between $1300 and $1600 for their tickets that allowed her to go -- that allowed them to go in. They had all access premium passes in order to go see AOC.

BARTIROMO: Yes, they did and she had a packed house. Karl, it's good to see you. Thanks so much. Karl Rove.

ROVE: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Great op-ed. Coming up, trouble for Facebook. The social media giant reportedly facing a criminal investigation now for handing over user data to major tech companies without permission. The fallout, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Deadly blizzard conditions in Colorado and across the country this morning. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, it's been something else. Good morning again. Nearly 3100 flights canceled over two days, most of them at Denver International after a bomb cyclone hit the airport there. Wind gusts as strong as 80 miles per hour. Now, the Colorado police officer -- elsewhere in Colorado, a police officer hit and killed while outside his vehicle helping with the car that had skidded off of Interstate 76.

Now, let's go to Texas. Small planes overturned in the municipal airport by high winds. They looked like toys. Strong winds also a major problem in New Mexico, sweeping a train right off of the tracks. And then there is some stunning video out of Texas. Look at this. Strong winds blowing over a tractor trailer. And this wasn't the only one. There's been reports of wind speeds up to 70 miles per hour, causing multiple trucks to blow over. No word, folks, of the condition of this driver, if he's OK or not. But wow, something else.

OK. Shares of General Electric lower in the premarket. They're forecasting adjusted earnings between 50 and 60 cents per share this year. That is below analyst expectations of around 70 cents. G.E. also says its industrial operations could burn about two billion more cash than they generated in 2018. There is the stock, actually it's higher in the premarket, 1-1/2 percent.

And then there is this. Next year's Major League Home Run Derby winner is going to reportedly get a nice little bonus, $1 million. That is according to the new agreement between the MLB and the players association. Other changes coming to the league include a single trade deadline and a three batter minimum for pitchers. All that starts in 2020. And those are your headlines, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl. Thank you. Coming up, Facebook is under fire this morning. The technology giant reportedly now under criminal investigation for the company sharing user data with more than 150 of the largest technology companies out there without permission.

Then game on. E.A. games reportedly paying the world's most followed gamer $1 million to play and promote the launch of Apex legends. The big business of gaming, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Facebook is under fire once again. The company reportedly facing a criminal investigation over controversial data sharing deals with technology giants including Amazon, Apple, Microsoft. Now, Facebook reportedly gave access to the personal information of hundreds of millions of its users to those tech companies. This after a major outage hit Facebook, Instagram and WhatApp across the globe yesterday.

Joining us right now is former prosecutor and criminal defense attorney at the Bianchi Law Group, David Bruno. David, good to have you.

DAVID BRUNO, PARTNER, THE BIANCHI LAW GROUP: Good morning. And thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the Facebook news.

BRUNO: Yes. This is -- the information comes from the New York Times through unnamed sources so let's start there. But if there's a grand jury investigation out of the district, it's criminal.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRUNO: It's criminal. This is unrelated to any of the administrative action, unrelated to the consent order, unrelated to Cambridge Analytica.

BARTIROMO: So what are the implications of a criminal investigation for Facebook?

BRUNO: Well, the grand jury subpoenas mean nothing, right? Because when we talk about criminal, you got to talk about presumption of innocence. Even for somebody that's charged, there's a presumption of innocence. And there's even more caution when it's just a grand jury subpoena. So in the event that crimes have been violated, it could be the corporation generally, could be individual officers, could be board members. You know, it's limitless when you talk about criminal law.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's not just this investigation. This is in the Eastern district of New York. There's also a securities fraud investigation going on within the Justice Department in the Northern District of California related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. There's the FTC looking into its behavior, did it basically violate a consent agreement that it signed in 2011 over again, shared data that deceived customers and consumers.

And then also, the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into their behavior. And what's going on is they keep saying that they're fixing problems, we're not doing this, and it turns up time and time again that they're not being quite frankly honest with the American people and regulators.

BRUNO: Great point. Especially on the consent order. Because they had problems releasing consumer data before the consent order in 2011. That's why there's a consent order. And they agreed not to release without the consent of the consumers. So the Cambridge Analytica issue is a potential violation and they're still looking at that. Like you said, that's the California stuff. But it's interesting because New York is different. I think the New York investigation is completely different than Cambridge Analytica, which could sign -- be a sign for problems for safety.

FORBES: So what exactly in New York is the crime they think?

BRUNO: Even Times article itself says we don't know. We don't know how long it's been open and we don't know what the scope is. All they know is that these two unnamed cell phone companies received grand jury subpoenas. That's going to be subpoena duces tecum for records. So they're probably looking at the agreement between Facebook and the cell phone companies as well as any data that was received in exchange between the two.

ORTAGUS: This is totally separate from Elizabeth Warren's proposal to break up the big tech companies but it certainly adds, you know, more political pressure and more weight to her proposal.

BARTIROMO: Do you think they'll break up? They will be forced to break up?

BRUNO: I was talking about this in the morning show a couple days ago. I think ultimately, yes. But right now, no. It would be under the antitrust laws. They could -- they could proceed under those laws or through new laws by Congress. That would potentially be something that could affect --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Congress will start by putting up roadblocks to additional acquisitions by these companies. Again, buying up the smaller companies and essentially buying them up and then shutting them down just to own and sit on top of technology that might be valuable and increase their market share. That would be the first step. It won't be breaking a lot.

BRUNO: When is Congress going to act? This was in the forefront last year when we were talking about Cambridge Analytica.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, they got --

BREAM: This is a completely different --

BARTIROMO: They got many of the CEOs to come down and testify --

(CROSSTALK)

BRUNO: Yes, exactly. Zuckerberg himself testified last year.

BARTIROMO: David, good to see you. Thanks so much. David Bruno there. We'll take a short break. When we come back, Tesla is gearing up for a big reveal. The company will unveil its Model Y SUV later today. We will tell you what to expect when we come back.

And then the college cheat scheme. Actress Lori Loughlin posted a million dollars in bond after appearing in Federal court yesterday while her daughter was reportedly onboard the yacht of the chairman of the USC's board of trustees. When the scandal actually broke, the outrage coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, March 14th. Your top stories right now, 8:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news, we're getting readings on initial Jobless Claims and Import/Export Prices. You'll see it on the screen momentarily. Futures, meanwhile, off of the lows of the morning. Dow Industrials now showing a decline of just 10 points. S&P 500 is unchanged, exactly where it closed yesterday. And the NASDAQ is up six points currently. In Europe this morning, gains across the board, pretty much all morning this morning. European indices look like this. Jobless Claims coming out, 229,000 as you can see. And the Ft-100 is up 41 points. The CAC Quarante is up 35 points. And the DAX Index in Germany up 39.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed. Shanghai was the worst performer, down 1-1/4 percent. Pushing back on the Green New Deal, top Republicans are calling for a hearing on the controversial Green Deal from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

Onto the latest on the college cheating scandal, one of the parents who was arrested, his son coming to his defense while casually smoking marijuana on the streets of New York City. Wait until you see this. Then pay to play, a new report says Electronic Arts paid top gamer, Ninja, $1 million to promote Apex Legends, all those stories coming up. But first, new economic data out this morning. We've got the Initial Jobless claims number. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, looking at a market that is pretty much back and forth, positive and negative territory all morning. Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: That's right, Maria. We've been looking at these numbers. I was just talking with a trader, that's why my attention was not on you. Initial Jobless Claims, this is actually higher than anticipated. So, you know, I got to tell you, we had such great news on the jobs market so far. I'm not sure traders are going to pay a whole lot of attention to this. As you know, it's a very volatile number week to week, the four-week moving average, 226,250. We come in at 229,000. It's a little higher, but not anything that's likely to move the markets here. Import/export prices, this is a turnaround and interesting, because what we've had are import and export prices that have been declining. Now, a turnaround, higher and higher than anticipated. The question here, is the government actually dealing with the real numbers now after the shutdown? They're still trying to get it together, I think. And there could be noise in these numbers.

We're going to talk quickly about Tesla here. They're coming out tonight with a Crossover SUV. It's going to be very big news. The Y, they will unveil it at 8:00 p.m. Pacific Time, 11:00 p.m. Eastern. They're going to live stream it on their website. This is going to be a lot of fun. You can see the stock up here one percent. It is the sister car of the Model 3, but 10 percent bigger, 10 percent more expensive, and slightly less range. This is the car that everybody wants to buy, the Crossover, the small SUV, is what's really selling in this country and frankly, across the world. It will be made at the Gigafactory in Nevada. That's the plan right now. But lots of questions, of course, about Tesla, how it's dealing with its debt. Those questions continue. That company frankly in turmoil as it prepares to roll out this new Crossover, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Gerri. Thank you. Gerri Willis there on Wall Street pushing back on the Green New Deal. Eleven house members are urging Speaker Nancy Pelosi to hold hearings on the agenda championed by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Joining me now is Oregon Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Greg Walden. Congressman, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. GREG WALDEN (R-OR), HOUSE ENERGY AND COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Hey, good morning, Maria. You got it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I've got the letter in my hand from many of you -- from you and many of your colleagues who have signed on on the bottom line here. You're urging the chairman to put hearings on this. Why? What's the point?

WALDEN: Well, we know from history that the last time this happened, Speaker Pelosi told the National Association of CountiesCongress had to pass Obamacare so we can find out what's in it. We don't want that to happen here. Look, the American people have a right to know what's in the Green New Deal, the effect it will have on their energy prices, on climate, on jobs. The AFL-CIO yesterday came out and said millions of workers in America would be adversely affected by the Green New Deal. Independent think tanks have said it caused out a $93 trillion would increase your energy bills by 22 percent.

We have a right to know what the left is doing here, what the Socialist Democrats are doing here, and my fear is they're going to cram through Congress like they've done other legislation, not give due process, not give hearings, and all we're asking for is let's have a hearing on this legislation.

BARTIROMO: No, we've been poking --

WALDEN: Roll out your plan.

BARTIROMO: -- holes in this plan from the get-go, on this program --

WALDEN: Right.

BARTIROMO: Because of the cost. As you said, $93 trillion. And also because, well, frankly, it doesn't make any sense to do away with fossil fuels within 10 years. We've have spoken with scientists and it's -- it can't be done basically.

WALDEN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: So do you think that a hearing would educate the people? I mean the pushback that we've gotten Dagen, right, is that this is just broad strokes. This is just an idea.

MCDOWELL: Yes, broad strokes like let's get rid of all --

WALDEN: Well, yes, right.

MCDOWELL: -- fossil fuels in this country.

WALDEN: Right.

MCDOWELL: And livestock --

MCDOWELL: Which, by the way, if --

WALDEN: And airplanes and everything else.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

WALDEN: And these are pretty radical broad strokes, by the way.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALDEN: This is pretty off the canvas stuff. And there would be policy that would follow, we know that. Look, we're open --

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, let me bring Dagen in. Let me bring Dagen in because we've both been really been poking holes in this from the get-go, Dagen.

WALDEN: Good.

BARTIROMO: How do you see it?

MCDOWELL: It would hurt the poor in America --

WALDEN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- and lower income Americans more than anybody else. We use fossil fuel, we use gasoline and natural gas because there are plentiful in the United States and inexpensive, number one. We are not a nation, given its size, that we can get around places on light rail. We saw the boondoggle out in California --

WALDEN: That's right. That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- which, again, has basically -- most of it has been shelved, the light rail project, the high speed trains there. Also, we're a leader in reducing emissions on the global stage.

WALDEN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: In the world in part because of natural gas. Emissions since 2005 have fallen 30 percent coming out of electric power plants because of the use of natural gas. So I don't -- again, did she cook this up at the bar late one night before she won her congressional seat after a little too much tequila? I don't know.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Congressman?

WALDEN: Well, I -- that's all spot-on. By the way, we have a housing crisis in my state and in my district, and this would drive up the cost of housing. You see what's happening in California with some of their radical ideas. The Civil Liberties Union and others are suing because the impact it has on the poor to drive up the cost of housing. Look, we have innovative ideas to reduce carbon emissions and deal with climate change as Republicans. We want an opportunity to put our ideas forward. , and to your point, by leading on energy development and discovery, by leading on innovation like battery storage, by putting forward new nuclear technologies, we can make the math add up but their math doesn't add up when you're going a hundred percent renewables in 10 years.

They want to get rid of livestock, airplanes. My district would stretch from the Atlantic to Ohio. There's no high speed rail going to get me home and around that district. And livestock's our number two ag commodity in my district and they want to get rid of that.

MCDOWELL: Just to --

WALDEN: I mean this -- none of this adds up.

MCDOWELL: Just to be clear -- I just want to be clear about something. I'm not making fun of this woman's job. We've all worked at some -- at one -- at one point --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- tending bar --

BARTIROMO: I was the coat check girl.

MCDOWELL: -- wait -- right. Waiting tables. We're not making fun of that. But we are making -- we are calling out somebody who's has gotten a lot of attention because one, she's an attractive woman and she's young and she knows how to use social media very well and personally, as a woman, I want her to be better. I want her to be smarter. I don't want her to spout nonsense, things that are not true about the unemployment rate in this country.

WALDEN: Right.

MCDOWELL: And how, you know, how many hours a week the average American works.

WALDEN: Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Just learn some facts.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but let's be clear. Nancy Pelosi is not going to put this down for a vote. I mean Congressman, your letter is urging the speaker to do that, but she's already locked arms with AOC.

WALDEN: We're asking for hearings. We're asking for hearings. Let's take a look at it. And what you haven't touched on is the fact the Green New Deal also includes a full government takeover of your health care.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

WALDEN: Read the data today coming out of England about wait times for cancer patients to get treatment. They're not meeting any of their mandates, any of their goals here. And we don't want long wait times in America and that's $32 trillion, a complete government takeover.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible.

WALDEN: And so there -- this is much more than just climate contained in the socialist manifesto. And I think Americans have the right to know and as members of Congress, I don't want this thing pulled up quickly and voted on without us having a chance to go through it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALDEN: And that's what we're asking for.

BARTIROMO: Well, you make a good point.

WALDEN: Can't we just have hearings?

BARTIROMO: You think you'll have the hearing? You think you'll have hearings on all of this?

WALDEN: I certainly hope so.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

WALDEN: You know, the Energy and Commerce Committee has a record of bipartisan work in these matters and I think there's an opportunity we should have a hearing.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, thank you so much for joining us this morning.

WALDEN: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Greg Walden there. Breaking news on Tesla, the company is announcing Zachary Kirkhorn the new Chief Financial Officer. Company also naming a new Chief Accounting Officer. This just coming out right now with these new appointments. CFO and new accounting officer at Tesla, stock is up, better than one percent right now. We'll take a short break. When we come back, Boeing is battling a major crisis. The U.S. has grounded all Boeing 737 Max aircrafts. Stuart Varney weighs in on that when we come back.

Then the big business of gaming, EA Games reportedly paying the world's top gamer a million dollars to play and promote the launch of Apex Legends. But first, a special update from the Tennis Channel right now.

DANI KLUPENGER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, guys, welcome back to another Tennis Channel court report. For FOX Business, I'm Dani Klupenger. The Superstars came out to play on day eight at the BNP Paribas Open. Roger Federer continued his excellent run off form as he look for a record sixth title in the desert. The 20-time major champion eased past Great Britain's Kyle Edmund in straight sets to punch his ticket into the elite eight.

Federer moves on to face Poland's Hubert Hurkacz for a spot in the final four. Earlier, Rafael Nadal barely broke a sweat as he dispatched Philipp Krajinovic to reach the quarters. The Spaniard closing out the impressive win at 6-4 after just under an hour and a half on court. And don't forget, you can watch all the action from the California Desert on Tennis Channel. Our live daily coverage hits the air at 1:00 p.m. Eastern. I'm Dani Klupenger.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the Federal Aviation Administration is grounding all Boeing 737 Max 8 airplanes in the U.S. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. I'm trying to put myself in the position of being an airline which has one of these Max jets on order. After all, there are 4,000 of these jets that are on order from Boeing, so you got airlines all around the world waiting to take delivery. Some of them are about to take delivery. What do they do? Here they've ordered a plane, which is now not allowed to fly. Do they take delivery? Do they have some kind of financial accommodation with Boeing? And this is not going to be fixed very quickly. The black box in the Ethiopian crash has been taken to Paris. It was badly damaged. They have special equipment there to get inside the thing and find out what happened.

That's going to take weeks, maybe months. So, it's a very long time before you find out exactly what happened, what is the problem with these jets and how do you fix it. In other words, you've got all these orders that are going out there and will the airlines take delivery? What's going to happen? It's the great unknown and I think it's a huge negative for Boeing.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: That's what I got to say.

BARTIROMO: huge, huge negative, for sure. I think, Stuart, this company is down 25 billion in market value --

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- just since the Ethiopian crash.

VARNEY: Yes. Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Pretty incredible. We've seen an impact, we'll probably see a continued one.

VARNEY: I have no idea the financial impact on Boeing.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: But in the immediate term, there is going to be a negative financial impact.

BARTIROMO: For sure. Yes.

VARNEY: How it works out, don't know.

BARTIROMO: I know you'll have more in about 10 minutes. Stu, we'll see you then. Thanks so much. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart at 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

First though, college cheat scheme. Actress Lori Loughlin is posting $1 million bond after appearing in court for alleged bribery to get her daughter into an elite university. We've got the very latest there. And then game on, the world's top computer gamer, Ninja, reportedly making $1 million to promote the launch of Apex Legends. The business of gaming after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More to that college admissions scandal. Lori Loughlin released on a $1 million bond and is scheduled to face a Boston judge with Felicity Huffman on March 29th. CEO Gregory Abbott and his wife, Marcia, also reportedly bought their daughter's way into school. Their son, Malcolm, coming to their defense while smoking pot on the streets of New York and promoting his mixtape, saying this, "They're blowing this whole thing out of proportion. I believe everyone has a right to go to college, man."

Joining me right now, reaction, is FOX News Contributor and "GREG GUTFELD SHOW" Correspondent, Kat Timpf, Former Obama Campaign Adviser and Democratic Strategist, Robin Biro, Dion Rabouin, Axios Markets Newsletter Author, and FOX News Contributor and National Security Analyst, Morgan Ortagus. Great to see you, guys. Well, I mean just the idea that he's on the streets of New York smoking marijuana in the face of this, what is he thinking?

DION RABOUIN, AXIOS MARKETS NEWSLETTER AUTHOR: That's not even a misdemeanor anymore, right? Now in de Blasio's New York, you know, that's just like getting a traffic ticket. So, hey, maybe his mixtape is hot, Maria.

BARTIROMO: No, it's still --

RABOUIN: Maybe it's --

BARTIROMO: -- not legal in New York for --

RABOUIN: No, no, it's not legal, but it's basically like getting a traffic ticket at this point.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ORTAGUS: It's gross. I'm so sick of smelling weed.

ROBIN BIRO, FORMER OBAMA CAMPAIGN ADVISER AND DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I was just going to say I can't walk down the street without getting caught in a cloud of weed smoke.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean it's probably going to go -- to go legal at some point. But the real point is it's not and this guy is sort of sticking his nose, you know, sticking his finger in the hurt by doing this.

BIRO: Yes.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: This is what happens when you have parents who will get you out of anything and everything.

BARTIROMO: Right,

TIMPF: And who will do anything for you. They make you so entitled --

BIRO: Entitlement.

TIMPF: -- that this guy is saying, "Oh, I'm going to be a rap star. I bet you -- " I mean I've not heard -- and I've not heard his CD, but I do not plan to listen to it.

ORTAGUS: Mixtape.

RABOUIN: His mixtape -- his mixtape might be hot.

BARTIROMO: His mixtape --

TIMPF: I just -- this is what happens when you're so entitled and you know your parents will get you out of anything. This is the way that you behave.

BARTIROMO: I thought --

BIRO: I'm not buying that mixtape at the gas station.

TIMPF: No. I hope his parents didn't spend money on him getting into college.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ORTAGUS: They probably buy him weed.

RABOUIN: I think they did. I think this one --

BARTIROMO: So do you -- do you think all the students involved are either going to be pulled out or it's too late for that? I mean they're not going to -- they're obviously not going to let anyone in who attempted to cheat.

BIRO: Like I said, pull them out.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BIRO: And send them to military school. As a vet, I'm all for it.

RABOUIN: Well, this scandal's been going on for years. I think they tracked it back to 2011 to 2018. So, some of these kids I think are still in college. Some of these kids probably have their degrees already and have moved on. Maybe they have jobs in, you know, prestigious firms. Who knows? Obviously some are out selling mixtapes on the street and smoking marijuana, but, you know, these kids are -- a lot of them I think have probably already graduated and moved on and really what do you do? You can't take the degree back.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I wonder how the students did in school given the fact they did pay their way in. Hey, how about this? Pay for play. Fortnite, great Tyler Blevins, known as Ninja, reportedly made $1 million for promoting the competition, Apex Legends. So, he's being paid to promote this.

TIMPF: What a life, to get paid for playing videogames. Everyone else plays videogames to the detriment of their career.

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes.

TIMPF: I think that good for him, wonderful, but I don't think kids should look at this and say, "See, mom and dad?"

BIRO: That's what I want to do.

TIMPF: "I don't got to do my homework. I'm going to be a millionaire by playing videogames."

BARTIROMO: If it works for him.

BIRO: But hey, if Kendall Jenner can get a quarter of a million dollars for one post on Instagram to promote the Fyre Festival, why not?

RABOUIN: And this is from the market's perspective, this was really a great thing for EA. They were falling behind other video game makers. Fortnite has really sucked all the air out of the videogame space and this really got EA back on top. I think they've got about 50 million users playing this game right now, which was the biggest launch in I think a long time, at least since Fortnite's been out. And their stock has really responded as a result, so.

ORTAGUS: I'm a capitalist. I'm all for people making money, whether it's through promoting videogames, reality T.V., like, you know, whatever.

RABOUIN: Yes.

ORTAGUS: Whatever, as long as you're making money, I'm not into socialism and free everything.

RABOUIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, speaking of making money, listen to this. There are now more wealthy households in the United States equivalent to the entire population of Sweden. Last year, more than 10.2 million households saw a net worth of $1 million to $5 million breaking a new record, according to a spectrum group survey. Pretty good stuff that you're seeing --

BIRO: Awesome.

BARTIROMO: -- so many millionaires in the U.S. and people lift out of poverty. That's capitalism.

TIMPF: Yes. Absolutely. It's a great thing. It's so hip to sort of demonize people for being successful, but that's not what this country is supposed to be out -- about. I don't understand where we reached the point where successful equals bad.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TIMPF: And, no, that's a great thing. It's a wonderful thing.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think about this whole debate about capitalism versus socialism? Good op-ed in The Journal today by Dan Henninger, socialism, yes, be afraid.

TIMPF: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts. Dion.

RABOUIN: Look, I don't know that socialism is coming to America. And, again, there are lots of different types of socialism. There's -- you've got Bernie on the left saying he wants Democratic Socialism, which it's important to point out is very different from what's happening in Venezuela and the situation there. You've also got places like Norway that have socialism, you've got Chile who had a socialist president. So, what that means is there's a lot of different things. I think a lot of people are quick to point at something and call it socialism.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's be clear --

RABOUIN: It's a broad spectrum.

BARTIROMO: -- this is federal -- this is a federal takeover of certain industries. And that's what Medicare For All is.

RABOUIN: But that's not what --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's what this Green New Deal is. So, these are socialist policies.

BIRO: I'm a little interested to see Nancy Pelosi herself pushing back on some of these. Basically with the Green Deal she kind of said, "Yes, that's cute," and just moved on. So, as a Democrat myself I was a little but relieved because I'm scared. I'm more of the, you know, I'm a Southern Democrat so this socialism stuff kind of scares me a little bit, honestly.

TIMPF: There's no doubt that the polling shows that Millennials and Generation Z are more in favor of socialism than any other generation.

BIRO: Right.

TIMPF: I just don't think they totally understand what it is. They think it's wearing like a Che Guevara T-shirt.

BARTIROMO: I think you're right. Great Millennial panel, guys. Thank you so much.

ORTAGUS: Thank you.

RABOUIN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Appreciate it. Kat Timpf, Robin Biro, Dion Rabouin, and Morgan Ortagus. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Great show. Dagen, Steve, Morgan, thank you.

FORBES: Thank you.

ORTAGUS: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Love you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: All right. Good morning, Maria.

Jun 16, 2017( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2].Via RealVision.com,[3]If You Only Look At One ChartTime is short, so here is one chart to get you thinking in a new direction. Velocity of Money (M2) M x V = P x TSource: Bloomberg The chart that no central banker wants you to see Velocity and inflation will continue to fall as long as debt compounds faster than GDP growth. The secular low in bond yields is still ahead of us. * * *Right Here, Right NowThe best trading ideas of the week from RVP ContributorsBuy some InsuranceSays Stray Reflections[4] In the past two decades the VIX has closed below 10 on only 11 occasions, and 7 of those occasions were during the past month.

Sound normal? 'Low volatility begets high volatility. Some participants shared painful experiences that taught them consistently betting on higher volatility is a fool's errand. Better to buy puts as insurance when option pricing gets too cheap. With the S...00's realized volatility down to just 7% (it has been lower only 3% of the time since 1928), now seems like a good time.'Jawad Mian's[5] report suggests that now may be the time to buy some put options to take advantage of a potential spike in volatility. With the time value of options so low due to suppressed volatility, now might be the time to take out a little insurance. Remember, you can't get it cheap when you need it most. Even deeply out-of-the-money, long-dated options could experience an asymmetrical payout in the event of a major unexpected risk event.* * *The Big CallLegendary hedge fund manager Stanley Druckenmiller said when you see something in the market that really, really excites you, 'Bet the ranch on it.' These are the Big Calls, the investment themes that can make or break you. Think differently from the crowd and have a different time horizon, and you have an edge. RVP, with its crack team of financial minds, identifies the Big Calls and guides you through the investment opportunities when they present themselves.Bond YieldsIn Limbo or Playing Limbo? We often refer to the state of being 'in limbo' as stuck on the edge of hell with no resolution But remember, limbo is also a dance from Trinidad in which people compete to dance lower and lower under a bar until someone eventually collapses. This week in The Big Call we ask, how low can global bond yields go; and what could raise the bar, or will bond yields be stuck at current levels forever? Bond bull alive and kicking? The secular trend of declining bond yields has seen prices rise inexorably during a 30-year bull market. Our call from April 7th was to go long TLT on a short-term view - which has returned a decent 3.5% to date. But how long can this return continue in the face of rising leverage and deteriorating demographics? That's something we considered in the Are You On This Yet? section of The Hack on May 19th[6] Drowning in debt Jawad Mian's thought-provoking symposium this week, A Dozen Ideas to Get You Thinking Differently[7], sets up our discussion nicely: 'The US economic return on additional debt has fallen to about 20 cents on the dollar. That means 80 cents is servicing existing debt, which has been borrowed for the purpose of supporting unproductive consumption and jobs. This makes economic growth very sensitive to changes in interest rates.'The diminishing return of each new unit of debt is making it harder and harder for governments and corporations alike to juice their growth and returns. With debt levels so high, the service costs become punishing. To avoid a default, interest rates must remain structurally lower for longer just to support the present debt. Furthermore, the debt has to grow just to service the exisitng debt. Think about that for a second? Are higher rates already the death knell for the US economy? 'It would only take a 20% backup in interest rates before the debt service becomes problematic (depending on duration and the amount of outstanding debt). The 10-year Treasury yield nearly doubled from the summer 2016 low, which suggests the US economy is about to slow down, rather sooner than later.'The economy is slowing, and yet with these debt levels across the world, the growth rate required to get out from under them is essentially mathematically impossible to achieve:The path of least resistance for central banks becomes structurally lower interest rates, since a widespread debt jubilee is too politically unpopular, for now. That comes later. Central banks are stuck between a rock and a hard place. how to prevent those low rates blowing up (even bigger) asset bubbles how to keep banks profitable so they can recapitalise organically how to have any levers of monetary policy left during the next major downturn Across the world central banks are in a bind, and so developed bond markets are sleepwalking toward a Japanese-style scenario of negative bond yields and a deflationary psychology. * * *Global bonds - The world tourChina At the government level Chinese debt-to-GDP looks very reasonable at around 43%; but if we add in all the local debt, state-owned enterprises, and other forms of debt we get estimates of more like 250% of GDP, which makes China look rather Japanese[8]. China does, however, have one advantage, which is a high GDP growth rate that can be used to shrink that debt load - but with so much growth generated from debt-fuelled investment rather than consumption, it will be hard structurally to grow the economy whilst weaning it off the debt. Chinese government bond yields have been on the rise, which may actually reflect positive fundamentals in the economy. As Jim Walker's Wealthy Nations[9] observed in March, 'The rise in rates is a reflection of success and economic acceleration, not a reflection of economic problems. China will increase interest rates not because the authorities are worried about over-indebtedness and/or the amount of credit being extended.'Cyclically, then, China seems OK for now - the PBOC has been stepping in with liquidity when needed as they try to steer the economy towards some corrective actions. However, the jury is out on how long they can keep this up. For more in-depth consideration of Chinese debt dynamics, remember to check out CrossBorder Capital's 'The Financial Silk Road[10]'. US The 10-year Treasury currently yields around 2.2%, a very low return by historical standards, especially when debt-to-GDP has ballooned to over 100%. Both metrics are now at their post-war level. Will foreigners question the US's creditworthiness and abandon their debt? As long as the USD remains the global reserve currency, demand for dollar debt will be high; and only the US bond market has the depth for this size of capital flows - i.e. many holders of Treasuries buy them for reasons other than risk/reward. OK - but the world could abandon the dollar Sure, but what's the next largest alternative? The euro Greece The Grecian debt crisis is now entering its seventh year of tedium. In that time debt-to-GDP has mushroomed from 126% to 179% - a debt level no nation has ever emerged from without some form of default or devaluation. Yet Greek bond yields have fallen from >30% in 2012 to just under 6% today. With a succession of bailouts, Greece has trundled along on life support. As the old Soviet joke goes, 'So long as they pretend to pay us, we will pretend to work'. But what do people who want euro-denominated collateral do, then? Germany The 10-year yields are on the floor - 0.25%! This is due to a flight to quality in the Eurozone: If the EU breaks up, you are best off with bunds because the Germans have greater fiscal rectitude (although debt/GDP is still near 70%), and a new Deutsche Mark would be worth a lot more than a freshly minted drachma. So what are we learning here? Bond yields - especially government ones - are not really reflecting economic risk/reward anymore. They reflect a belief that central banks will ease into perpetuity - or at the very least a belief in the 'greater fool theory'. This isn't theoretical economics confined to classroom textbooks; we only have to look to Japan to see this train wreck in action. Japan Japan has a debt-to-GDP ratio of 250%! Yet the 10-year bond yields just a handful of basis points. What could possibly explain this? Deflation. Decades of deflation have meant that owners of any fixed monetary asset will see its value increase over time. Japan was stuck in a debt-deflation cycle until the recent advent of 'Abenomics' - the competitive devaluation and money-printing game that everybody else had been playing. Either way, Japan has avoided default through extremely low interest rates, extremely high domestic bond holdings, and a highly cohesive society, all in combination with a weak currency and an export-led economy. Is this the future for other developed sovereign bonds? The BoJ have only a plan A: Buy up all the bonds in issue. And after that? You can be sure that Japan will be at the vanguard of the next economic and monetary experiment. Remember that debt jubilee I mentioned? Japan Debt to GDP vs Japanese Bond YieldsSource: BloombergCould we see a bond scare?The reality appears to be, it's unlikely. Yes, an individual country like Greece can suffer a huge bond scare, but for larger nations with printing presses such as the US and Japan, the most likely outcome is simply more debt and more devaluation. And with plenty of money sloshing around chasing too few assets, bonds will probably continue to be bid. The only thing that would reliably kill the bond market is higher interest rates from central banks. The trouble is, higher rates would also kill the market for everything else and trigger a depression. Could an inflation scare occur? Demographics, unproductive debt, and technological advancements put the chance of a sustained period of inflation pretty low, despite (or because of) the best efforts of Central Bankers.Baby Boomers are compounding the problem.As we noted in The Hack on April 7th, 'Baby Boomers Coming of Age[11]', the backdrop of an ageing demographic and massive pension black holes will structurally cap any rise in interest rates. 'According to the Federal Reserve, unfunded state and local pension obligations have risen to $1.9 trillion from $292 billion since 2007. Throw in the private sector and that figure is far greater. At the same time pension funds have been pushed up the risk curve as interest rates from fixed income are simply inadequate. Baby Boomers have never been more exposed to equities and are going to start to drawdown their capital for retirement.'The paradox is this: To fill that black hole and provide fixed income for retirement, we need bond yields above, say, 5%; but with yields above 5% the ability to service the debt mountain collapses and assets are liquidated. Wealth is devastated. Then, all those retirees will be shifting assets from equities into fixed income in the next decade, driving a huge wall of money into a bond market with diminishing yields.What about cyclical considerations?We have been stating for some time that the credit cycle[12] is rolling over. Just last week Michael Lewitt[13] noted: 'I no longer expect interest rates to rise significantly from current levels in the current cycle; they are more likely to fall as the economy stays weak and debt continues to build in both the public and private sectors. We could see short-term 25 or 50 basis point spikes in longer rates (10-30 years) based on an errant comment by a central banker or some piece of news, but rates are likely to stay down until the current business cycle, which is very long-in-the-tooth, ends.'With the Fed raising rates into a slowdown, they will have to backpedal in the near future to soften the economic blow.How low can we go? The limbo continues - and the bar goes lower. For now, it is hard to see any alternative to more debt and lower rates. The inflection point where we could grow our way out of this debt straight jacket has passed. The secular low in interest rates appears to still be ahead of us. Are You On This Yet?In such a fast paced world staying on top of relevant market news and developments is tough. RVP scours the globe for the most interesting stories and distils them, keeping you ahead of the crowd.BrexitTax-it? Brexit may be hanging in your mind as one of those tail risks you are supposed to worry about but cannot quantify. In The Hack for May 26th[14] we looked at the importance of UK/EU trade and politics amidst what appears to be a messy divorce with a potential EUR 100bn price tag. The EU debt crisis remains the elephant in the room, with poor demographics, massive welfare commitments, huge debt loads, and a one-size-fits-all currency to bind the mix - the potential for a full-blown crisis remains as real as ever. Is the UK just the first rat to leave the ship?Is it all doom and gloom for Britain?This week Eurizon SLJ Capital[15] published an excellent report outlining the potential opportunity for the UK to become a tax haven upon exiting the EU. What if Britain just refuses to pay the ransom note, endures a hard exit, and then steals all the EU's corporate business? What if the breakaway from the EU allows Britain free rein to shape its own industrial policy? Stephen Jen of Eurizon SLJ Capital argues that once free from EU encumbrances, the UK could move forward with corporate tax cuts to fuel greater inward foreign direct investment (FDI). The UK is already the greatest recipient of FDI in Europe. The UK has a strong base of FDI due to credible institutions, strong rule of law, the English language, high-quality human capital, and good infrastructure. The opportunity for greater future FDI could be huge if the FDI stock matches that of other tax havens as a % of GDP: Check out Switzerland, Ireland and Luxembourg.Source: OECD , IMF, Datastream and Eurizon SLJ CapitalUK in the Sweet SpotIf the UK sparks a boom in FDI, taking business away from the Eurozone by having a more competitive corporate tax rate, that shift would have effects akin to the competitive devaluation of currencies we have seen since the GFC. But tax havens act differently: They have to be small enough to attract business away from larger economies but still large enough to retain the social and economic depth required to support large businesses. Britain appears to sit in the sweet spot: 'In the middle - what we call 'Middleweight' economies - we may have a sweet spot for corporate tax cuts. The loss in revenues from the reduction in the tax rate may be easily offset by the new inflows of foreign investments. If the costs for a company of operating in London were driven lower, we believe this would tilt the balance on FDI flows away from, say, Dublin. The point here is that larger and more sophisticated economies command a premium on smaller economies that can.'This analysis gives a read across for the Trump tax cuts for investors. As the US is a 'heavyweight' and really operates its tax system under its own gravity due the sheer weight of its GDP and global importance. In the case of the US, cutting corporate tax may actually hurt the fiscal situation rather than having the impact of attracting enough FDI to compensate for the tax cut.Surely cutting taxes blows up the fiscal balance sheet?It may be that reducing the corporation tax rate further to a 'sweet spot' actually attracts more investment from abroad and results in more job creation in the UK, putting money into the pockets of residents and giving the government a greater tax base from personal income. Corporate tax is after all a form of double taxation[16] - both the corporation and its shareholders are taxed on profits and then dividends.There's got to be more to Britain's chance of success than just tax cuts?To have a winning formula you also need industrial policy: 'It would make sense, in a medium-sized economy like that of the UK, for there to be (i) more guidance and leadership from the government and (ii) concentration of financial and intellectual resources in the development of industries In a globalised economy that offers 'winner-takes-all' propositions, or non-linear financial rewards, there is a role for the government to lead and nurture the industrial development process, in our view.' Currently the UK ranks no. 7 in the World Bank's Doing Business[17] report, above Germany, Ireland, and Austria. Denmark is the only member of the EU to rank higher. If Britain can continue to attract FDI and see it invested wisely in profitable and scalable sectors, there could be a winning formula on hand for greater growth outside the EU. Even if you have Brexit exhaustion, you need to read Eurizon SLJ Capital's[18] analysis - it is incisive and comprehensive and deserves to be a white paper floating onto the desks of leaders across Europe to drive forward some more functional politics. Does Theresa May have the balls? Britain has its destiny in its own hands. It needs a bold government to make some bold decisions, but otherwise, all the ingredients are there for success.So Much Volatility, So Hard To FindPicking up pennies in front of steamrollers Volatility is an oft-used measure to gauge risk in financial markets. This week we explore a few facets of volatility; and we ask why, with so much uncertainty in the world, is volatility so low? Jawad Mian's Stray Reflections[19] this week explores the correlation between the VIX and the Global Risk Index.What is Volatility Telling US?VIX vs Geopolitical Risk Index (rhs)Source: Bloomberg, Federal Reserve Board, Goldman SachsIs VIX is a poor measure of risk?Despite rising geopolitical risks and lofty market valuations, the VIX Index has been recording new consecutive lows. In the past two decades the VIX has closed below 10 on only 11 occasions, and 7 of those occasions have been during the past month. Jawad rightly asks, 'Are we going to see policy uncertainty decline and volatility stay lower for longer, or are we about to enter a higher volatility regime?'Volatility tourists?JP Morgan's Marko Kolanovic sees the death of the human investor[20] as one of the key drivers of declining volatility. Only 10% of trading volume is currently derived from fundamental discretionary trades. Quant strategies and ETF algorithms are accounting for most of the trading, and their setup represses volatility. This happens because many of the quant strategies follow the same big-data and trend-following factor-based approaches. Volatility has been trending so low that yield-seeking 'volatility tourists'[21] are joining in the party, seeing the low VIX readings as a chance to gain some yield in an apparently benign macro environment.Show me the volatility!To put it another way, it is quite possible that the sheer weight of money currently flowing into short volatility positions, the implied central bank put, and the rise of passive investing and quantitative funds may be clipping potential volatility. Taking a different slant on our recent featured piece from 720 Global[22], these forces are making the graph on the left look more like the one on the right;Source: 720 Global What that means is that the volatility of actual returns is increasingly resembling a random walk!OK, I sort of get it - but what's the big deal about volatility?Here we must cede to a master class from Chris Cole of Artemis Capital, whose 'Volatility and the Allegory of the Prisoner's Dilemma'[23] is truly a piece of essential reading for any investor. If you want to get a handle on this crucial concept, you need to watch Chris's Realvision TV[24] interview. One of his key mantras is this: 'Risk cannot be destroyed; it can only be shifted through time and redistributed in form.'Currently, suppressed volatility is merely storing up risk for the future, explosively; and the principal reason for this is that market participants believe central banks will be there to backstop any future random events that would otherwise cause significant stress in the market. Of course, this unwavering belief invites moral hazard and is driving the trade in shorting volatility. Central banks are in effect driving up the occurrence of apparently 'everyday' events and pushing out tail risk:Source: Artemis Capital, Bloomberg The key takeaway here for investors comes when Chris says, 'Peace is not the absence of conflict.' A simple way of thinking about this is that the active conflict between bulls and bears discovering prices in the market each day is for now being drowned out by the waterfall of cheap money pouring down from central banks. But the bulls and bears are still there - waiting.Here's the bottom line.When a risk event occurs that a central bank can't or won't step into, the volatility tourists are likely to be ruined, and the markets will be primed to for severe dislocations in pricing - something which the quants and algos aren't programmed to navigate.Staying AheadThere isn't time each week to discuss everything that is going on in markets. Here we piggyback on previous RVP Weekly Hack talking points and let you to explore some stories further.Who hit the bid? The SNB did.[25]If you need a sign of the times, check out the breakdown on the NASDAQ holdings of the Swiss National Bank. As the SNB fights to reinvest its vast foreign exchange reserves, it has become a large buyer of US tech stocks. In fact it now owns 3.75% of Apple and 3% of Amazon! In the first quarter the SNB increased their holdings of US equities across the board by ~25% - hardly selective buying. It seems some central banks are in fact propping up the markets in quite a direct fashion. When we think about the meteoric growth of passive investing, we need to consider that ETFs may not be the only price-insensitive buyers - there are institutional ones, too.Tech companies make ripe pickings.[26]Are US regulators now looking to initiate trust-busting moves against the big tech companies? With the likes of Amazon and Google becoming increasingly dominant in their chosen fields - and choosing new fields every week - the motivation and incentives to increase regulation of these sectors is obvious. There is a geopolitical angle here. In the period following the GFC, the US extracted a number of fines from European banks that needed to shore up their finances, whilst the EU engaged in various trust-busting activities against the likes of Facebook and Microsoft. Think of this as a kind of modern resource nationalism. Are the US regulators about to turn on their own? urn:contentItem:6106-92Y1-F03R-N2RB-00000-00Book Bits: 3 October 20202020-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:30ZLexisNexisBook Bits: 3 October 2020James Picerno

Oct 03, 2020( The Capital Spectator: http://www.capitalspectator.com/ Delivered by Newstex) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1647820065/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1647820065&linkCode=as2&tag=thecapitalspe-20&linkId=335044afbbef43759e90da162d52b9a1● When More Is Not Better: Overcoming America's Obsession with Economic Efficiency[1] Roger L. Martin Summary[2] via publisher (Harvard U. Press) Growth in the economic prosperity of the average American family has slowed to a crawl, while the wealth of the richest Americans has skyrocketed. This imbalance threatens the American democratic capitalist system and our way of life. In this bracing yet constructive book, world-renowned business thinker Roger Martin starkly outlines the fundamental problem: We have treated the economy as a machine, pursuing ever-greater efficiency as an inherent good. But efficiency has become too much of a good thing.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1984879979/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1984879979&linkCode=as2&tag=thecapitalspe-20&linkId=d913d9086c0b0b33d18b61c0396c80be● Big Dirty Money: The Shocking Injustice and Unseen Cost of White Collar Crime[3] Jennifer Taub Review[4] via San Francisco Chronicle 'White collar crime, like cancer or influenza, comes in many forms,' legal scholar Jennifer Taub writes in her blood-boiling new book, 'Big Dirty Money,' where she examines white-collar crime in America and the ensemble of forces that enable it. Since these frauds profit by deception rather than violence, they are often considered 'victimless crimes.' Not so. As Taub eloquently sketches, the victims are 'the elderly couple who loses life savings to a Ponzi scheme. Hurricane victims who suffer twice when housed in toxic-gas-emitting trailers. The hard-working high school senior rejected from college because a classmate's family paid off a coach to gain admission https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1594632596/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=1594632596&linkCode=as2&tag=thecapitalspe-20&linkId=5c115b93eb8a9de14df9e434889fbfeb● The Modern Detective: How Corporate Intelligence Is Reshaping the World[5] Tyler Maroney Summary[6] via publisher (Penguin Random House) Today's world is complicated: companies are becoming more powerful than nations, the lines between public and corporate institutions grow murkier, and the internet is shredding our privacy. To combat these onslaughts, people everywhere — rich and not so rich, in business and in their personal lives — are turning away from traditional police, lawyers, and government regulators toward a new champion: the private investigator. As a private investigator, Tyler Maroney has traveled the globe, overseeing sensitive investigations and untying complicated cases for a wide array of clients. In his new book, he shows that it's private eyes who today are being called upon to catch corrupt politicians, track down international embezzlers, and mine reams of data to reveal which CEOs are lying. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/019026070X/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=019026070X&linkCode=as2&tag=thecapitalspe-20&linkId=d87b832265fbbaae188fd13098862210● Taming the Megabanks: Why We Need a New Glass-Steagall Act[7] Arthur E. Wilmarth Jr Summary[8] via publisher (Oxford U. Press) In Taming the Megabanks, Arthur Wilmarth argues that we must again separate banks from securities markets to avoid another devastating financial crisis and ensure that our financial system serves Main Street business firms and consumers instead of Wall Street bankers and speculators. Wilmarth's comprehensive and detailed analysis demonstrates that a new Glass-Steagall Act would make our financial system much more stable and less likely to produce boom-and-bust cycles. Giant universal banks would no longer dominate our financial system or receive enormous subsidies. A more decentralized and competitive financial system would encourage banks and securities firms to fulfill their proper roles as servants - not masters - of Main Street businesses and consumers. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/125024062X/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=125024062X&linkCode=as2&tag=thecapitalspe-20&linkId=e2b00b8ff3a89ee998597bc30307049f● Liberty from All Masters: The New American Autocracy vs. the Will of the People[9] Barry C. Lynn Review[10]via Washington Monthly Barry C. Lynn, author and executive director of the Open Markets Institute, an antitrust advocacy group, has been sounding the alarm about monopolies for years. In his new book, Liberty from All Masters, he insists that monopolies are ultimately a political problem. As surely as Americans are citizens in a democracy, they are citizens in a political economy. But with their far-reaching and subtle powers, monopolies undermine our agency in the economic sphere of life. Indirectly, they threaten democratic self-governance, too. ● Trampled by Unicorns: Big Tech's Empathy Problem and How to Fix It[11] Malle Gavet Interview[12] with author via Bloomberg Malle Gavet, Former COO at Compass, discusses her new book 'Trampled by Unicorns: Big Tech's Empathy Problem and How to Fix It.' She talks about why it's important for business leaders to care about the impact their companies have on the world. ● Out of the Ether: The Amazing Story of Ethereum and the $55 Million Heist that Almost Destroyed It All[13] Matthew Leising Excerpt[14] via Coindesk Bloomberg News reporter Mathew Leising's new book, 'Out of the Ether: The Amazing Story of Ethereum and the $55 Million Heist That Almost Destroyed It All', tells the story of the infamous DAO [decentralized autonomous organization] hack that almost brought down the world's second-largest blockchain. Please note that the links to books above are affiliate links with Amazon.com and James Picerno (a.k.a. The Capital Spectator) earns money if you buy one of the titles listed. Also note that you will not pay extra for a book even though it generates revenue for The Capital Spectator. By purchasing books through this site, you provide support for The Capital Spectator's free content. Thank you!
