Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T73-VKP1-JB20-G2SX-00000-00Booz Allen Hamilton Holding Corp at Citi Global Technology Conference - Final2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:30ZLexisNexis090618a11865495.795Booz Allen Hamilton Holding Corpat CitiGlobal Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Horacio D. Rozanski

Booz Allen Hamilton Holding Corporation- CEO, President & Director

* Lloyd W. Howell

Booz Allen Hamilton Holding Corporation- Executive VP, CFO & Treasurer

Conference Call Participants

* Jonathan Phaff Raviv

Citigroup Inc, Research Division - VP

Presentation

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV, VP, CITIGROUP INC, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is day 2 of the CitiGlobal Tech Conference. Doing something slightly different. I'm Jon Raviv. I cover aerospace and defense for Citigroup. We're honored today to have this afternoon Booz Allen Hamilton's CEO, Horacio Rozanski; and CFO, Lloyd Howell, joining us.

Booz Allen Hamiltonis one of several companies that is in the government services space, providing a lot of mission-critical type technologies and other services to a variety of government customers. I'll let them -- while the CEO go into more detail, but I just think the concept is being that the government also has technology requirements and there are companies out there who are uniquely suited to addressing those technology requirements, and thus, Booz Allenis here at the CitiTech Conference. So thank you, everyone, for joining us. I'm going to toss it over to Horacio to give a couple of brief minutes on what's going on, what you're seeing. But then, we'll just have general Q&A. So feel free that I can run, but feel free to raise your hand and butt in any time, push to talk on the microphone. I think I don't -- I don't think I have forgotten anything. So with that, I'll hand it over to Horacio. Thank you, Horacio.

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI, CEO, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, BOOZ ALLEN HAMILTON HOLDING CORPORATION: Thanks, Jon, and good afternoon, everyone. I -- we're eager to answer your questions and not hear ourselves talk. So I will give you a couple of highlights from Booz Allenjust to ground anybody who's new to the story, talk a little bit about our investment thesis and then launch us into Q&A.

So if you know Booz Allen, we've been around since 1914. We started serving the United States federal government in 1940 by helping the Navy get ready for World War II, and we have been serving the Navy ever since. We have served -- we now are a $6.2 billion firm, roughly 40 -- 24,000-plus employees spread all over the states and many other countries. About 97% of our work is for the federal government and the remaining 3% is for, what we call, global commercial, which is the private sector in the United States as well as private and public sector clients in selected places around the world. I have been in this job for about 3.5 years. About 6 years ago, when I was a Chief Operating Officer, we launched a strategy, which at that time we thought we were very clever by calling it Vision 2020. If you read the Wall Street Journal, apparently everybody else called their strategy Vision 2020 as well, but at least we did it in 2012.

The core of that strategy was to get us closer to our clients' missions, to increase the technical content of our work, to double down on innovating and expanding our capabilities at the leading edge of technology and to reenter the commercial market, which we have exited when we did a -- when we spun off that business as part of the transaction with Carlyle in 2008. Happy to say, Vision 2020 has been very successful for us as a strategy. The business is growing and performing very well. And last June, we had an Investor Day where we laid out our investment thesis and parameters for the next 3 years. And if I may, the thesis have 3 parts. The first one is that in a market that now signals demand, we believe we are uniquely positioned to capture upside. Because of the investments we made in Vision 2020, because of the way we are positioned and because of our operating model, we believe we will outgrow and outpace the market consistently, which is also consistent with the last couple of decades of Booz Allenhistory.

Second is that, financially we can deliver for our investors over the next 3 years a 50% increase in ADEPS going from about $2 last fiscal year to about $3 by the end of a 3-year period through a combination of top line growth organically in the 6% to 9% range, 10 to 30 bps of margin improvement over this time period and deploying about $1.4 billion to shareholders in the form of both ordinary dividends and possibly share repurchases or other vehicles to deploy effectively capital back to our shareholders.

And then the last thing is that because of the investments and because of the work that we're doing, the Booz Allenstory of growth and opportunity extends beyond the 3-year horizon by, what we call, option value, which, in our way of thinking, is the ability to take some of the intellectual capital that now sits inside our business and monetize it in new and different ways by building businesses that are not necessarily labor-based but that take advantage of what we have learned to do for the government and drive it into new and exciting footprints. We talked at Investor Day about investments we're making in artificial intelligence in work for the federal government that will expand. Beyond that work, we're doing in directed energy that has opportunities to monetize. Work we're doing even with the park services around reservation systems that create different business models to capture value. Those numbers, if and when they pay off, will pay off outside of this 3-year period. And because we cannot exactly quantify them, we talked to them about really, "This is the option you buy on top of the base value of our business if you own the name." So that's, in general, where we are and what we're seeing. I think I've stuck to the 5-minute mark as we discussed. So Jon, I'm going to turn it back to you.

Questions and Answers

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: Even slightly less. Again, anyone should feel free, just raise your hand, I can call on you. But one thing I wanted to capture here, I know the future is very important, but I think understanding a little bit of the past is also relevant here, especially with Vision 2020. Can you talk about some of the changes or the evolution of the company that you've undergone in the past -- during your new tenure here because I think it's important the sort of way you pivoted to address what the government wants today versus what they wanted 5, 6, 10, whatever years ago?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: So if you look at our market, our market has gone through 2 significant periods of change and is now entering a third one. There was a significant uptick of funding to the entire federal government post 9/11. And in that market, the entire business grew, the entire industry grew, and obviously, we grew as well. A lot of the work that grew at that point for us was work around program management, around outsourcing, around intelligence analysis and around the support of the country through those conflicts. The second period came, call it, around 2012, 2013 in the form of sequestration, where there was a significant drawdown of budgets and not just that but a tremendous period of uncertainty for all of our clients, where, frankly, they didn't know what their mission was going to be, whether they were going to be funded and open for business the next day, and be paralyzed in lots of ways the functioning of our government, but certainly the functioning of the interaction between government and our sector. And then started really over the last couple of years is a period of greater stability, greater certainty in the -- for our clients in terms of what their missions are and how they're going to accomplish them, and in the last 18 months, an increase in funding that accompanies that, which signals the opportunity to invest in capabilities that our clients have long wanted to implement, moving significant portions of their active structure to the cloud, for example, implementing mobile platforms that our clients understood the value that they had to the private sector and the value they could have to their mission, simply they were not funded, didn't have the resources to go after that. And what we're seeing now is a period where the resources are there and a real run towards making those upgrades and modernizing those footprints. In that context, around 2012 and coming off a long period of expansion for the firm, we sat back in this process of, what we call, Vision 2020 to say, "Okay, the market of the future is not going to be like the market of the past." And the notion that because we are a very well-respected consulting firm with long and deep footprint in the government isn't going to be sufficient as the basis for competition and differentiation for us in the future. And so we begun to invest in an innovation agenda that has taken our business to a different place and in building much more technical content for our work, so that we could be more relevant to transforming the missions of the future. Take an example, work we do with Veterans Affairs, that has greatly helped decrease the number of -- the backlog of claims for veterans because we have taken a number of their aging infrastructure pieces into the digital domain with completely different dynamics and a much greater ability to serve those customers. Work that we do for the IRS around helping not just with the tax return part of the mission but with actual fraud detection in tax returns. I'd like to tell the story that my own return was hacked a few years ago, and the IRS caught it and did not issue a refund to a bad actor. And I'd like to think that somewhere in there, Booz Allensystem and algorithm was part of preventing that problem. That's the firm that we are now, a firm that lives at the intersection of these core missions and the application of technology to create value to the mission, both technologies that are today in broad applicability and broad use across the private and public sector, like Agile development, like I said, like mobile, like cyber, like data science, and technologies that are just coming into being, like blockchain, like cyber on the IoT side, and AI and so forth.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: Guys want to pick you up on that one. I think one interesting program that you all talked about on the last conference call, and I think you've talked about sort of individual capabilities as the conference calls go on, but I think the one thing from the last one was a program that seems to be the forefront of artificial-intelligence-type implementation at the Defense Department. And perhaps it's surprising -- well, maybe not surprising at all that the defense department for as strong and large as it just simply doesn't do certain things, but now they're starting to do certain things. What are those? Can you give us a sense for what those sorts of things are? And how it represents a new almost market for you all?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: So the reality is DoD has been at the forefront of innovation and experimentation for this country for the past 40 or 50 years. The Internet was conceived at DARPA, and this is not something DoD doesn't do. But for the past few years, they've been in a position where they didn't have the resources to get beyond the pilot and the basic experimentation into broad application of some of these technologies. So the program, Jon, that you're talking about is the program where we're working with the defense department to first build the architecture and then the technology platforms so that very broad and different streams of data can be brought together so that you can build actual neural networks and deep learning algorithms in order to accelerate the sifting of that information and collecting of that information so that it can be used operationally. Imagine a group of soldiers down the field and an analyst trying to figure out by reading reports and seeing sensor data from different types of sensors, real time, "What do I tell these people is in front of them? And where might the enemy be? And what do they need to worry about?" We are now in a position to begin to build those capabilities at scale. We're not the only ones doing that, but in our sector, we believe we are further ahead than anybody.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. Just to that point, I mean, if you look at some of your competitors and a lot of them also seem to be moving down the technology path, so how we should look and can compare like versus Leidos and Perspecta? How do you differentiate yourselves when it comes to technology and providing cybersecurity solutions, et cetera, like if I look at you and try to explain someone what makes you different?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: So I think I would say 2 things. One is, in a couple of specific areas, I do believe that because we got started sooner or we've been investing for much longer, our capabilities are that much further ahead. We started doing cybersecurity in the intelligence community in the mid-90s before cyber was a thing. And that -- we have learned and created a depth of knowledge and of relationship and capability there that will be hard for others to reconstruct. We started -- we built a, what we call, the Strategic Innovation Group, which is roughly a couple of thousand of our colleagues focused on driving these new capabilities into the market 6 years ago, long before even the defense department started talking about innovation, long before DIUX came into play. So we have been getting ahead of that in ways that have allowed us to just the time to build those capabilities to a different level. More importantly, though, because of our consulting heritage, we are not into deploying technology, we are into creating value from that technology. So a lot of the work that we do and where we are most effective or most differentiated is when we bring together 3 things. One is the deep mission knowledge that comes from professionals who have served those clients and have actually at times been those clients, going back not years but decades. And so they really understand the problem set, and they really understand the solution, and they understand the barriers to adoption. Two is, we do bring unique technical capabilities, usually fused together as opposed to as individual offerings because one of the things our operating model allows us to do is to pull from different parts of the organization very quickly to solve problems. And three, we have the consulting process that starts with defining the strategy and ends with the change management approach that actually creates value from deploying that technology as opposed to saying, "Hey, here's a cool new tool. Hope you can see something in it that others can't see." We go all the way to the value creation point, and that makes the relationships more enduring, the opportunity higher and the work more valuable, which is why our win rates are what they are, which is why we have outgrown our peer set and our market going back, really, a couple of decades.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: I'll pick up there on the idea of outgrowth. The outgrowth has been notable and continues to be notable versus your peer set. And I think one of the things that you all have -- someone will ask, why are you doing this? And one of the words that comes up is unique positioning. And I think it's relevant to understand and you just brought this up, is that the unique positioning isn't specifically -- isn't specific to a customer, it's specific to a capability. So can you explain how the business is structured to enable that sharing across -- cross-capabilities that quickly and that flexibly?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: So the core of our differentiation from an operating model perspective is the notion that we have one P&L. This goes back to operating asset partnership back when we were a partnership and retaining that ethos even to this day. So all of the senior people at Booz Allen, which we internally still call partners, are compensated on essentially the same bonus pool, which is tied exclusively to the performance of the entire firm. What that does for me in my job is I can arrange for amassing of resources against a new opportunity or redistributing of resources against existing opportunities real time. What can take a more traditional organization weeks to do, we can do in an afternoon, not necessarily because we're any smarter or we work any harder but because we don't have any of the barriers to get it done. I can take resources from one part of the business and apply them to another without having to restructure everybody else's incentives, metrics, bonuses or anything. We simply just go. And that has allowed us the opportunity to bring really novel thinking to the government. And people think of the government as a client. It's a market made up of lots of different clients with lots of different understandings in different places in their own life cycle. So what is new to the department of x has been an implementation for 10 years in the department of y and the fact that we have done it in one place and can bring it to the other and can bring the people that have done it so seamlessly, frankly, gives us speed to market. In a market that is as turbulent as the government market has been over the last decade, that has been a real source of advantage for us because agendas change very rapidly, priorities change rapidly, funding changes rapidly and you need to be able to adapt and change your resources around, again, almost real time and without -- and we have a lot of advantages to do that. I'm not saying that it's perfect or that we get it right all the time because that would be hubris, but I -- we have inherent advantages in the way we're structured to get that done.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: On the way to this 3-year target, there's the sales side of the equation and you talked about 6% to 9% CAGR over that period. There's also the margin side of the equation. And I think you guys -- I mean, first of all, I'll pull back and just say -- or just prompt you to talk about how you change -- how you're thinking about messaging on the investment thesis these days in terms of what -- thinking about how Booz Allen's quarterly results fit into a longer-term path? And why that was an important thing for you all to achieve in terms of shaping that conversation?

LLOYD W. HOWELL, EXECUTIVE VP, CFO & TREASURER, BOOZ ALLEN HAMILTON HOLDING CORPORATION: Sure. I've been in this role for a little over 2 years, and I grew up on our client-facing side. So I don't really come into the role as much as from an accounting perspective as I do from a client competitive business planning perspective. So one of the things that I was struck by is the conversation we were having with our investors was different than the conversation that we had about the business internally. And Horacio and I said about the business of how do we begin to converge the 2 conversations. And what we discovered is it really starts with how we plan the business. So in early June, we laid out a 3-year financial objective profile that Horacio talked to, which is really based upon how we plan the business. Our account leadership looks at what's before them, the opportunity set, the whitespace, the competitive landscape and then they put forward their best thinking about what to do. We made a commitment on, to your question, Jon, in early June, as to why we felt we could achieve that. And it's really because we pick it up from the trenches and we see what's out there and then we go forward. The challenge with or the opportunity with achieving that is, if you look at our performance and our backlog, all the demand indicators give us a lot of confidence that we're not demand-constrained at all. The challenge particularly in this job market is we better recruit the talent especially with the skill sets that are in high demand, not only by our sector but by many industries. Sourcing and recruiting that talent really helps us to convert the backlog and go forward. Now last year, we added over 1,300 people to the business. At Q1, we were up year-over-year by about 5%, and we're likely to have a similar hiring pattern to what we had last fiscal year. So that gives us even additional confidence about achieving our intended investment thesis and the objectives. With just one quarter under our belt and given that it was a strong quarter, naturally, we got a lot of questions about are you going to make an adjustment? And 1 quarter into a 3-year journey is not, I think, bode for start making adjustments on the fly. But we're off to a great start, and it gives us a lot of confidence that we have finally been able to marry the 2 stakeholders in terms of our internal operators as well as our investment base. And now a lot of the questions that we get are consistent with that investment thesis, whether it's, "Can you do a little bit better? Or where you'll end up in the range? And what would contribute to 10 versus 30 basis points of improvement." Now we feel that we've got at least the framework to have that discussion.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Sorry. I'm not familiar with the story, but I mean there a lot of big tech companies here that are talking about organizing themselves, not along product lines but along solutions with their own consulting and engineers to provide sort of bespoke solutions. I just kind of wonder what it is which kind of ultimately differentiates? Is it your trusted -- your long-term trusted partner status with the government and federal agencies. Presumably, you're taking other people's solutions -- technical solutions and deploying them. So how does that work medium term?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: I think you have it right. I think, first of all, we are unique in the depth and breadth of our understanding of our clients and of their missions and the amount of time we have spent in there. But we pair that with this operating model that is really meant to integrate things and to fuse things together. And I know a lot of people talk about that and lot of people think about that. We've been doing that for the vast majority -- I've been with Booz Allenfor 26 years. We've been doing that for 20 of the 26 years, and we have now, to some degree, perfected that to a science. And so we are extraordinarily capable at taking technology solutions, whether we develop them, whether we act in partnership with someone else or whether we recommend somebody else's technology solution and bring it in into clients to create no-kidding value. And at least, in our sector, where there are significant barriers to entry do it at scale, in terms of the regulatory requirements, in terms of the accounting requirements, in terms of clearances, in terms of actual access to these programs, that gives us a degree of uniqueness that frankly others don't have. We are not going to compete -- if we go head-to-head with a technology company purely on technology, there may be a couple of areas like cybersecurity where we may actually have more. But in many of those areas, we are not going to be able to differentiate ourselves. So that's not what we're trying to do. We're not trying to say we know more about cloud and the cloud providers that we know more about anything than anybody. We are trying to say on some of these areas we do, but on the majority, it is the ability to fuse these things together with a real understanding of the mission in order to create value inside that mission. That is particularly important if you think about it from the government's perspective because there's a real price to pay if you're a senior government official for getting enamored with a shiny object that doesn't create value in terms of the oversight that they're under and being able to demonstrate that they've done all of this and it created value. It's not just I took my systems to the cloud -- it is I took my systems to the cloud and I accomplished x because otherwise, this becomes a discussion have I wasted a lot of taxpayers' money, which typically ends up on C-SPAN or on TV somewhere. So the ability to reliably create value is what we're after, and it's the core of what Booz Allenhas been about, frankly, certainly since 1940.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I heard you loud and clear, and I appreciate your comment on the demand side. I'm just thinking, in terms of all the geopolitical pressures right now, given the preponderance for a large chunk of your revenue base coming out of the Navy. The Navy is focused -- the Navy is concerned about Russian expansion in the Eastern Mediterranean. We know where the concerns lie or come from in the South Pacific. Given all of those threats, real or potential, at the moment, what do you sort of see as perhaps further uses of your services as your product portfolio, service offerings stand today? And how proactive are you with the DoD, generally, Navy, specifically, in terms of down the road potential further offerings?

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: Very. So just to give you a sense of our portfolio because I don't know that I covered this early on, as I said, 97% of our work is with the federal government. If you took that, half of it is with DoD, rough terms; about 1/4 is with the intelligence community; about 1/4 is with the civilian agencies. So we are very broad based. If you think about the half, that is DoD as an example, and so -- and that is distributed across all of the services and all of the major components of the Department of Defense. We started in the Navy in 1940, and we're very proud of that association, but these days, Booz Allen serves the entirety of DoD. And in a lot of what we do is to engage our clients not just on today's program but on how some of these capabilities will affect their ability to deliver and accomplish their mission in the future. That is the core of what we have to do to stay ahead for 2 reasons. One, because we need to shape the market to accept those services but also because we need to get reads from the market as to what's going to sell there when. So we are constantly engaged. I was just in the Pacific myself a couple of weeks ago having some of these conversations with clients at senior levels and at mid-levels trying to understand how they see the world, how they see the threats. What are those threats they feel they have a good handle on which of those threats they feel they need more thinking, more help, eventually more capability around. And I'm just one person. This is what we do collectively all the time to try and get a real pulse of what's going on and to the extent that we can to try and shape those conversations so they're productive and so that some of these discussions get some play. I think part of the challenge that many of our government clients have, by virtue of how their market works, is they hear about some of these things but they don't know the true implementability of these technologies in their environment. Blockchain is really interesting. But what can you do with blockchain if you're in the Navy? Really, no kidding. And to what extent would that improve upon the mission, say, around logistics and management of supply chain, which is the traditional place in which you would use blockchain in that context. We have perspectives on that. We have experts that have done it. We have implementations of those things in other parts of the government, which then gives our clients some certainty that these things will create real value. That's really our role. We didn't invent blockchain, and I won't argue that we're the ones that know the most about it in the world; I think that would not be true. But what I will tell you is we have done real no-kidding implementation of blockchain solutions in the federal government. And that gives other federal clients a degree of security that if they really want to try it, they're talking to somebody who knows how to implement these technologies and create value in their environment against their requirements. I'll give you an example that is more accessible. I apologize, it's a little trivial but I think it'll speak to you. I was -- a few years ago, we bought a company, a small company that the core capability that they have was UI UX, user interface, user experience, for the design of government websites. And I sat down with them to try and understand what is it that they did that was so interesting. I mean, it's not like website design is the new technology in 2017, but the requirements that a government entity has, especially around accessibility where people with disabilities in creating a website are unlike anything the private sector faces. And to create actually a seamless meaningful user experience for a government website that meets all of the regulatory requirements that sit around it is that much more difficult than it -- then, say, for Booz Allen's website. And that's the kind of thing that we increasingly work on and try to figure out is. Again, not can you use this technology, can you use it in these particular environments given the unique challenges and requirements that these environments have. And not enough people, frankly, are doing that and that's the source of opportunity for us.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And last question. And there have been, like, a number of events, I guess -- like, Har T. Martin, Snowden and Department of Justice investigation. And has that impacted your relationship with the government in any way? And do you feel like if there were another one that could potentially? And I guess, has the noise, I mean, performance and share pricing to be exceeding expectations. So has there been any impact?

LLOYD W. HOWELL: The one thing that has been consistent, each incident has its own sort of facts and circumstances, but we have historically approached any challenge in a transparent open dialogue with our clients, our investors and our people. And going back to the Snowden and then Martin, and now most recently Justice, we've approached it the same way. We have not seen to-date an adverse impact on our business neither in the form of being able to pursue -- being invited to pursue opportunities, winning, attracting talent, onboarding talent. When we have lost, it's usually been on traditional reasons, pricing, maybe someone has a better technical approach, but the current manner that we're addressing has not been the reason why. And we are working through a dedicated external and internal legal team to address the government and any questions that they may have. But a little over a year ago is when we disclosed that we're aware of investigation. But frankly, this is a process that takes some time, and we don't have any new information to share with you today other than it has not to date impacted our ability to succeed in the market, whether it's with talent or with business.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: Question on capital deployment. And before I do that, I'd be remiss to not also mention that Nick Veasey is here, who is the Head of the Investor Relations, but also used to wear a heat that was more M&A focused, strategy focus as well. He's here, so you can bother him about these questions. But on that topic, there's been consolidation in this market of government services. You all have stood out at least by not being heavily involved in some of the larger deals, which is perfectly fine. But can you sort of give a sense for how you consider -- how you screen for those sorts of opportunities? And perhaps, why you have not been involved thus far in that kind of activity?

LLOYD W. HOWELL: Sure. M&A remains one of the levers as part of our overall capital deployment strategy. In June, we made a commitment that we were going to deploy $1.4 billion over the 3 years. $400 million of that will be due to our regular recurring dividend, but for the remaining $1 billion, we've got M&A certainly one of the levers that we look at. We look at over 100 opportunities every fiscal year, and we've been very selective for a couple of reasons. One is, our strategy emphasizes capability, development and expansion. So to go out and do $1 billion, let's call it, plus acquisition would fundamentally take us off of our strategy. And we feel we would get distracted trying to integrate and assimilate such a transaction. So capability tuck-ins, reemphasize or emphasize and reinforce our current strategy. And so we have bought an Agile developer, a managed services company, but again on the smaller side and ones that we feel we can integrate. The other thing I'd offer up is today's multiples in pricing are a bit richer than what we feel we can make work given our sort of economic profile and what we aspire to do. So for assets that are out there, we feel they're not meeting with, a, either our quality standards or our economic expectations. And then, again, it comes back to our confidence level on whether we can integrate and it can be a multiplier in the positive way as opposed to a distraction. With the organic performance that we've had, we want to complement that. We don't want it to take away from what we've been able to do over the past couple of years. So that's how M&A fits into our overall thinking and then our capital deployment.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: That's fair. If you're growing 9%, someone might say, "Oh that's inorganic, right?" And the answer to that question is, "No, it's organic."

LLOYD W. HOWELL: Right.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: Fair enough. In the last 3.5 minutes, unless there's something else out there, I wanted to get a sense also on the growth side. Just some more thoughts again going 3 minutes on the option value side? What the excess could be? I know you can't quantify it, but the sorts of things that you're developing internally that could be applied across new opportunities, new customer capabilities.

HORACIO D. ROZANSKI: Sure. So at the very core, there's a number of things that we do for the government that are unique and that are at the leading edge of what anybody is doing for or with the government, in areas of cybersecurity, directed energy, artificial intelligence being 3 primary examples, and then some of the work we're doing around bringing the government, leapfrogging into full digital relationship with the citizen is the fourth area. And in each one of those, there are certain things that we believe can be monetized in different ways. We've shared at Investor Day, this last Investor Day, our story around AI and the kinds of opportunities that we see in order to creating train models primarily in the areas of intelligence and cyber that we believe would create significant upside. And by significant, I mean anything that would move the P&L 5 to 7 years out by a significant number, tenths of percentages. We've shared in the prior Investor Day an initiative we had at that time, which is now a full-blown opportunity, which was called District, which was a solution to being able to use mobile devices in classified settings, because it operates at the chip level; it's chip level cyber essentially as opposed to software level cyber. We have talked about directed energy and the fact that we had some of the leading contracts in the use of laser, some microwaves, particularly on the weapon side and trying to think about, "Okay, what can we build, what can we create using that knowledge that fits specific market niches, where our military would significantly benefit from having those capabilities people in the field." And so each one of those has a business plan. Each one of those is running as a business opportunity. I don't expect all of them to succeed, but the threshold to get into the pipeline is if we have -- it's a business that would produce several hundred million dollars at maturity, several hundred millions of additional revenue at margins that are often times 2-plus times the margins that we get for our labor-based business today. So in my way of thinking, again, if we have 5 and we get 1 to succeed, that would be a significant driver of future profitability and margin enhancement. If we get more than 1 to succeed, Lloyd and I end up on a cover of some magazines somewhere. But it is a -- it's exciting as an opportunity. It's exciting for investors. It frankly allows us to flex muscles. We haven't flexed in the past. And from a talent retention standpoint, it is crucial because it gives our talent, especially our most sought-after technical talent, the opportunity to work on different kinds of things, to chart more of their own destiny, to feel like they don't have to do the same thing over and over in their careers, which, frankly, will keep them around much longer. So if all we got out of this is that, that would be a tremendously valuable thing, but I believe we will get beyond that, in due time, a significant business upside as well.

JONATHAN PHAFF RAVIV: Okay. Great. It's as if you've done this before, Horacio. You took us straight down to the 0 second count. So thank you, and thank you very much, Horacio and Lloyd, for being here, and Nick. And also thank you, everyone, for participating here and also on the line, have a great afternoon.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XKV-CFW1-JDJN-628N-00000-00Borat versus Social Media: Sacha Baron Cohen Comes out Swinging2019-11-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:30ZLexisNexisBorat versus Social Media: Sacha Baron Cohen Comes out SwingingDr. Binoy Kampmark -

Having made a name for himself causing cringing controversy, forging alter egos with the ease of a spam producer, Sacha Baron Cohen (Ali G, Borat, Bruno) has taken a plunge into waters swum by every indignant activist, commentator and show pony worth column space in the media scape. The target is predictably dull, normal and soporific: the digital monsters of Silicon Valley and their tyrants as demon conjurors.

Baron Cohen's venue for attack was the Never Is Now Summit hosted by the Anti-Defamation League. In under half-an-hour, the recipient of the ADL's International Leadership Award took YouTube, Facebook and other tech giants to task for not policing that old, troubling matter of disinformation and nasty content.

"One thing is pretty clear to me: All this hate and violence [in the world] is being facilitated by a handful of internet companies that amount to the greatest propaganda machine in history." And so does Baron Cohen fall for the trap of presuming that such giants, unlikeable as they might be, are the mediums that confect the message, the propaganda ministers who run the global information program of hate.

He makes the mistake of assuming that reach and access somehow qualify as production and control. "Facebook, Google, YouTube, Twitter and others, they reach billions of people. The algorithms these platforms depend on deliberately amplify the type of content that keeps users engaged: stories that appeal to our baser instincts, and that trigger outrage and fear." Baron Cohen ignores the other base instincts: the cute factor, the cuddly animal, the emetic pet videos that stream through the infoverse and are likewise shared with algorithmic fetish.

Obviously, Baron Cohen's point here is that the machinists and the designers are flawed for simply giving the searchers of information what they want. They are the diviners of shallowness, grubby, naughty, and insufferable. "It's why YouTube recommended videos by the conspiracist Alex Jones billions of times. It's why fake news outperforms real news, because studies show that lies spread faster than truth." My, oh my.

Baron Cohen's own stance on disinformation acts as a rich double. "I've spent most of the past two decades in character. In fact, this is the first time that I have ever stood up and given a speech as my least popular character, Sacha Baron Cohen." He prides himself on the art of deception, the false show, the hidden message, but condemns its dissemination by the tech giants and their algorithmic squaddies.

The British comedian is famed for playing a figure who dissembles and forges false identities, advertising them as authentic to the gullible and moronic. The bumbling, potty-mouthed Ali G, who played a faux ghetto lout from Staines more black than black (the character itself was distinctly milk white often clad in a yellow tracksuit) ensured that those he interviewed were similarly seduced by the show. Only afterwards is the unsuspecting interviewee aware that their interlocutor has deceived them.

Several notorious cases of this abound in the Baron Cohen cabinet of wonders. The interview with the late Tony Benn, veteran stalwart of British Labour, comes to mind. With Borat, the sharpness becomes positively perpendicular. He moved his way through the United States causing havoc with Borat: Cultural Leanings of America to Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan. He was sued by Romanian villagers in New York for having misrepresented their village as a Kazakh enclave of retrograde rapists, prostitutes and thieves untouched by history. The Kazakh government expressed concern about the depiction of a country considered "terra incognita for many in the West".

A theme has also been picked up in Baron Cohen's attack, best noted by Casey Newton in The Verge. "As a rich celebrity who has no need for the free communication tools [social media] provide, and who can thrive without relying on the promotional benefits that come with active use of the platforms, blasting Big Tech costs Baron Cohen nothing." And please thank social media for making his speech on the ills of social media viral.

Nothing here detracts from the necessary contribution Baron Cohen has made to humour and satire. Borat was a vehicle to out anti-Semitism; Bruno the flamboyant flamer of a hairdresser drew out homophobia. (Ironically enough, a former president of the ADL, Abraham Lincoln took issue with Baron Cohen's use of anti-Semitic jokes in 2012. "You're not going to eradicate it by making fun of it.")

Nor is this to say that Cohen does not sport relevantly directed salvos against the information complex that has grown out of Silicon Valley's behemoths. The algorithmic directions do give the marginal and repulsive centre stage. The prospects for radicalisation do exist. But he leaves various things unanswered. There is no consideration about the implications of censorship or control of content left in the hands of such giants. Silicon Valley companies are also being co-opted as mutual regulators, with content commissars keen to ensure that matters offensive or reprehensible are not disseminated.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg himself has picked up on this thread of reasoning. In April in the Washington Post, he opened the door for greater government regulation of social media entities. "Lawmakers often tell me we have too much power over speech, and frankly I agree." He made all the right signals for state officials, suggesting that governments pass laws on, "Harmful content, election integrity, privacy and data portability."

But as is shown by the passage of such legislative instruments as the FOSTA-SESTA law, intended to target online sex trafficking, the object is often avoided. Instead of reducing sex trafficking, the law seems to have had the effect of emboldening pimps and increasing their market share. Websites rushed to self-censor; Reddit kicked several communities associated with sex work off its platforms while Craigslist removed personals altogether.

Even more troubling is Baron Cohen's suggestion to amend section 230 of the Communications Decency Act making social media companies liable for what their users generate or post. As the current reading goes, "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider."

This is simply too much for the comedian. If internet companies can be held responsible for enabling paedophiles to use sites to ensnare children then "let's hold these companies responsible for those who use their sites to advocate mass murder of children because of their race or religion."

Nothing would be more fitting than a genuine chastising and limitation on the power of these digital daemons. But Baron Cohen saddles them with a blame that ignores social evolution and behavioural expectations. It is also politically immature, giving the censors an all encouraging green light to control how users access and respond to shared material. The social media giants have mastered what is essentially intrinsic in modern shallowness, the discourse of the "like", the "share", the "upload". But to give them the full ambit of paternalistic control steered by state officials, castigating them for algorithmic negligence, is merely one part of a broader problem that remains historical: What do we allow people to see and who makes that decision?

Dr. Binoy Kampmark was a Commonwealth Scholar at Selwyn College, Cambridge. He lectures at RMIT University, Melbourne. Email: bkampmark@gmail.com

The post Borat Versus Social Media: Sacha Baron Cohen Comes Out Swinging - OpEd appeared first on Eurasia Review.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VSP-H6F1-DXH2-60FX-00000-00Border Battle; Rapper Hussle Shot Dead; NY Bans Plastic Bags, Adds Mansion Tax, Congestion Pricing; The Mueller Investigation; Walgreens Not Quitting Cigarette Sales Yet; T-Mobile's Phone Booth Gag; Best Companies To Work For; Michigan State Upset Duke; Auburn Beats Kentucky; Sharp-Shooting Robot; Reynolds Offering Hunger Harness Again After Big Super Bowl Response2019-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:30ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTTiana Lowe, Mike HuckabeeNEWSFinancial040101cb.231Border Battle; Rapper Hussle Shot Dead; NY Bans Plastic Bags, Adds Mansion Tax, Congestion Pricing; The Mueller Investigation; Walgreens Not Quitting Cigarette Sales Yet; T-Mobile's Phone Booth Gag; Best Companies To Work For; Michigan State Upset Duke; Auburn Beats Kentucky; Sharp-Shooting Robot; Reynolds Offering Hunger Harness Again After Big Super Bowl ResponseMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Susan Li, Liz Peek, Liz Peek, Lauren Simonetti, Jared Max

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi there, ladies. Thank you so much and good morning, everyone. Happy Monday to you. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Monday, April 1st, April Fools' Day. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Easing concerns about a slowdown in China, a pair of manufacturing reports shows a rebound in activity in China. We've got all the news driving global markets this morning and we do see a global rally. The battle over the -- securing the border is on. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire border with Mexico as funding is cut to three Central American countries. And then what's old is new again, T-Mobile unveils a phone booth, taking a jab at AT&T, but the joke may be on you. The story coming up. Plus, Toyota gets in on March madness. The robot cannot dunk or dribble, but it can sink a three-pointer. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

All right. Futures are pointing to a big rally this morning, take a look at stocks, up 176 points on the Dow Industrials, as the second quarter kicks off today. The Dow and the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ up at least 11 percent in the first quarter. Big quarter for markets, as you see this morning, we kick off a new quarter with a triple-digit gain, up 177 points on the Dow Industrials, up 18 points on the S&P, and the NASDAQ right now up 69 points. Investors are watching some key economic data. We did get the upbeat news out of China yesterday. We were talking about this on Friday. We've got the China PMI above expectations. That was the manufacturing sector news. It was, of course, a busy week last week, and it's going to be a busy week this week, with the March Jobs Report this Friday.

Let's turn to border security meanwhile, President Trump threatens to close the border with Mexico if it does not do more to stop illegal immigrants from reaching the United States and cutting aid to three Central American countries. I spoke to South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" yesterday about the crisis situation at the border now.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC), SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The president declared he is likely to shut down the border, the Southern Border, unless Mexican authorities immediately halt all illegal immigration. We've got two caravan coming -- two caravans coming to the country right now. Your reaction to the President's threat.

GRAHAM: We've had a hundred thousand people cross the border illegally in March alone. We're on track to over a million this year if it keeps up. So, Mexico could help more, they should help more. The triangle countries, 70 percent of the people coming here illegally come from three countries.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GRAHAM: We need those countries to help more. So if the President feels like that the only way to control this problem is to move the people from the port of entry to the ungoverned spaces where we need a wall --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

GRAHAM: -- I will support him.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the Washington Examiner, Commentary Writer, Tiana Lowe. Tiana, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us. What kind of an impact would that have, shoving -- shutting the border? And we should point out other presidents have shut the border entirely.

TIANA LOWE, COMMENTARY WRITER, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: So the big issue with our border is less, you know, the physicality of it and more are asylum laws, so the issue is that, you know, anyone who winds up on American soil, which is before where any physical barrier is, can simply claim asylum and as long as they go to one court date, they're usually released. So, I think -- I mean the constitutionality of shutting down the border will come into question, but this is a President empowered, empowered by the Mueller report, empowered by the fact that Congress failed to override his national emergency declaration, so he will do what he wants.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point. You know, having said that, the reports show that over a hundred thousand immigrants are expected to have crossed in March alone. So, we're talking about a hundred thousand in March, you just heard Lindsey Graham say a million in the entire year. What's your reaction to actually the activity right now at the border?

LOWE: So we're obviously seeing heightened traffic because word gets around, word gets around that our border security is sort of overflowing, there's too much work for -- to be done with the amount of resources that we have on staff, and more than anything, it's these asylum laws. Every reporter that I've spoken to goes down to the border, they all say the same things, the problem are the asylum laws less than the physical barriers. If the laws themselves are broken, then there's not much that any physical fortication or fortification can do to stop it. So, it is just a word of mouth situation. If people know that there is a good chance that they won't get caught, there will be increased activity.

BARTIROMO: I mean is there anything else the President can do at this point?

LOWE: I mean, this is why messaging is so important and the problem with Trump is that he takes -- I mean the President takes issues that should be broadly popular and terms them into 50/50 issues. You know, enforcing existing immigration law should not be controversial. Democrats have been taking this hardline position. If Trump makes the message not about Muslim bans, not about vastly changing our existing immigration laws, but about enforcing what's already there, that's the messaging more that he should not have a large ability to lose, because I think that most people agree, in order for us to be a sovereign nation, we must have borders.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, I mean most people agree, but they agree differently on how to solve it, right?

LOWE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I mean the President now is fighting a battle in the Congress even --

LOWE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- to get the -- to get the appropriate money to actually finish building the wall.

LOWE: Yes. And the difficulty is that every single time he's -- he is apparently sidestepping Congress in the national emergency declaration, trying to re-divert funding, it makes it seem as though he's the aggressor rather than just the person who's trying to enforce existing American law, and that's why messaging here is so important.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LOWE: The American public has to be on his side.

BARTIROMO: All right, Tiana. Thanks for very much for weighing in here. Tiana Lowe joining us there. Meanwhile, a well-known rapper shot dead in broad daylight in Los Angeles. Cheryl Casone with the details in headlines there, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, good morning. Well, Grammy-nominated Nipsey Hussle was one of three people shot outside a clothing store that he reportedly owned. The shooter still on the run, two others were rushed to the hospital. Celebrities like Rihanna, Pharrell Williams, and LeBron James all posting tributes to the musician online. The rapper claimed to be a gang member on his Facebook page. We should add the father of two was just 33 years old.

Well, Britain's Parliament set to hold more votes today on alternatives for leaving the European Union. That's as Prime Minister Theresa May plans to bring her proposal back before lawmakers for a fourth vote. Parliament has rejected May's plans three times. Today's vote could include a softer deal that could set up a customs union with the E.U. Meanwhile, easyJet is saying the uncertainty over Britain's divorce from the E.U. is pushing ticker prices lower. The discount carrier saying that demand for flights is actually weakening.

And let's talk about what's happening here at home, Dumbo falling short at the box office, but still soaring above the competition. The Disney remake earning an estimated $45 million domestically at the Weekend Box Office. That was below analysts' expectations of around 50 million, but, again, still making some money and, hey, it's Dumbo, Maria. Who doesn't love a little Dumbo?

BARTIROMO: Yes, who doesn't love it? Exactly. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, 2020 vision accusations against former Vice President Joe Biden now. It happened after a former Democratic legislator made the charges. . His response to that coming up. Then T-Mobile going nostalgic, the phone company unveils a phone booth, but there is a catch, we will tell you all about it when we come right back right here. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: All right. We got a big program this morning. Coming up right here, California Congressman and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy is with us this morning, Pennsylvania Congressman and House Budget Committee Member, Dan Meuser is with us this morning, along with FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Radio Host, AM 970, and former SNL alum, Joe Piscopo here as well, don't miss a moment of it. We got a big three hours coming up.

We want to kick it off right here with this news on Joe Biden, the Former Vice President and possible 2020 contender, is defending his behavior this morning after being accused of inappropriately touching Former NevadaCongress -- Assembly Woman Lucy Flores back in 2014. Now Flores is speaking out for the first time on this, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LUCY FLORES, FORMER NEVADA ASSEMBLYWOMAN: Very unexpectedly and out of nowhere, I feel Joe Biden put his hands on my shoulders, get up very close to me from behind, lean in, smell my hair, and then plant a slow kiss on the top of my head. It was shocking because you don't expect that kind of intimate behavior. You don't expect that kind of intimately from someone so powerful and someone who you just have no relationship whatsoever to touch you and to feel you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Wow. Biden released a statement yesterday in response and he said this in part, "In my many years on the campaign trail and in public life, I have offered countless handshakes, hugs, expressions of affection, support and comfort, and not once, never, did I believe I acted inappropriately. If it is suggested I did, I will listen respectively. But it was never my intention."

Joining the conversation this morning is FOX Business Network's Susan Li along with Former Presidential Candidate, FormerArkansas Governor, Mike Huckabee, and FOX News Contributor, Columnist for The Hill, Liz Peek. It is great to have everybody here this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE (R), FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Thank you.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: This news coming in a very inopportune time for Joe Biden just before he wants to announce that he's going to run for president, Liz.

PEEK: Yes. The problem is we've seen so many instances like this over the years, and he's gotten a pass. Time and time again, when he leans in, he hugs people, he kisses them, you know, look, we don't know really know whether anything ever came of any this, whether people were really uncomfortable. This woman is, you know, she was a Bernie Sanders supporter, so there's some back and forth about was this the Bernie Sanders campaign, was it Beto O'Rourke, she went to his rally over the weekend, who knows? Maybe it was politically motivated, but the answer is it was creepy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PEEK: Bottom line, it was creepy.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's what it sounds like, Governor.

HUCKABEE: Well, it is creepy, but I have to say I don't think Joe Biden is a sexual predator.

BARTIROMO: Uh-huh.

HUCKABEE: I think he's a creepy old guy --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: -- who is a little hands on --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: -- and all that, but I mean, most of the things he's done, he's done in a very public place.

PEEK: True.

HUCKABEE: It wasn't like he invited women up --

BARTIROMO: That's true.

HUCKABEE: -- to a hotel room or an office by himself. This is stuff he's done with a thousand cameras on him and he did it anyway. So, I just think this is Joe, and I kind of like the guy, you know.

BARTIROMO: I know.

HUCKABEE: I mean I do. But this -- the timing of the person coming forward, a little suspicious just before he announces.

BARTIROMO: Right. Why she --

HUCKABEE: If it was that uncomfortable --

BARTIROMO: Why she -- exactly.

HUCKABEE: -- why didn't she say this a year ago or the day after it happened? The fact that she does it on the cusp of his announcement, a little suspect.

BARTIROMO: Do you think she's for Bernie Sanders? Is that what this is about, a Bernie Sanders opponent?

HUCKABEE: It sounds like it could be, or maybe she's for Beto, you know --

BARTIROMO: Oh, no.

HUCKABEE: -- but she's not for Joe, I think that's pretty clear.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's really clear.

HUCKABEE: But one thing we know, she ain't a Biden supporter.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. Why wait until now? It happened in 2014.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

LI: She waited five years to discuss this when, you know, Joe Biden does have a history of changing his mind, whether or not he runs for president.

PEEK: Well, she says it's because all of a sudden he could be president. And she sort of felt like this is the moment to actually say something, that's her, you know, that's the --

LI: Well, why not 2016 then?

PEEK: -- as she answers why.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So that's why, because he's running for president.

LI: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: She's making no secret out of it.

LI: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, the path continues to get wider on the Democrat's side, but every time we hear policy, if we are hearing any policy from any of this of the -- of the contenders, it's socialist policies, it's pretty incredible what this -- what the lineup is looking like going into 2020, don't you think?

HUCKABEE: They continue to go further and further to the left, and each candidate wants to outleft the other.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HUCKABEE: And I think what they're going to do, they're going to outleft their own party because there are a lot of democrats in the country who are who are sane, moderate Democrats who are not as far out there on the socialistic issues both economically, as well as socially. They're not for afterbirth abortion, they're not for late-term abortion, they're not for higher taxes, and they're not for open borders, and they're finding themselves increasingly left out from this Democratic Party.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PEEK: It's not just their party, it's the country. I don't the country's on board with these --

HUCKABEE: No.

PEEK: Policies. As you -- I mean you just rattled them off, but these are really extreme positions they've taken, open borders, I don't know anyone who supports that even on the left, so -- except the people running for 00 running for president. What are they thinking?

BARTIROMO: Not to mention -- not to mention abortion in the ninth month of the pregnancy.

PEEK: Yes. Oh, my gosh.

BARTIROMO: That's actually absurd.

PEEK: It's horrifying.

LI: Well, AOC was defending her Green New Deal on Friday night, and he -- she was basically saying that this is a new generational stuff, you know. It's very meta. IT takes a young mind to understand it, but when, you know, as a younger person, you're looking at $40 trillion, I just do the math, and I think how are we going to pay for this? I know everybody wants free education, better education, they want better health care, at the end of it, I don't know if they understand that the bill does need to be paid by somebody.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LI: And eventually be them.

BARTIROMO: Actually, Douglas Holtz-Eakin's group says that the Green New Deal is going to cost $94 trillion for the Green New Deal. And look what happened last week, they all got a shot to actually put their money where their mouth was.

LI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And what did they do? They either voted no or they voted present for the Green New Deal.

PEEK: They voted present. They ran for the hills.

HUCKABEE: I mean deep down, everybody knows you're not going to get rid of airplanes and cars in 10 years. You're just not.

PEEK: Exactly.

HUCKABEE: Nobody can swim that far to Hawaii or Europe. It's -- we're not there yet. And the other thing --

BARTIROMO: We're not there yet.

HUCKABEE: -- when we talk socialism, people need to ask Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez, name one country on planet Earth where socialism is working right now. Tell us just one place where it's really --

PEEK: Not 300 million people.

HUCKABEE: There's -- but --

BARTIROMO: Well, Bill Maher tried to make this argument the other night on his show, and he said that the Nordic countries, Denmark, Norway --

HUCKABEE: That's not -- no.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, that's what he was saying.

PEEK: But actually those countries --

LI: But taxes are 60 percent in Sweden and Norway.

PEEK: Those countries are rolling back with their high taxes and their -- because they've all experienced big influx of immigrants, and all of a sudden, the model that seemed to work very well does no longer work. So, in Fact, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, they've all started rolling back their big safety net, et cetera, it isn't working anymore. So in fact there is no country anymore that really sort of epitomizes what these people want to do.

BARTIROMO: They've tried to have market principles there though as well as --

PEEK: More or less.

BARTIROMO: Yes, more or less.

HUCKABEE: Well -- and like Norway, they had enormous energy --

PEEK: Yes, yes.

HUCKABEE: -- resources there that was paying for a lot of this stuff.

PEEK: That's right. It's funded.

HUCKABEE: So it wasn't like it was a pure socialism. Everybody just tossing everything to the government.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

HUCKABEE: Divvy it back out.

BARTIROMO: Right. That's right.

PEEK: And by the way, in terms of the generation thing, AOC'S approval ratings now way under water. So, it isn't like this is really resonating with a big sector of the population, I don't think.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good point. We're going to take a break. When we come back, we got the China manufacturing data, it hit a six-month high. And then this, selling cigarettes a Walgreens could be a thing of the past as they're attempting to get into these CBD game to rival CVS. More on that coming up. Then winter is coming to Las Vegas, the famous Bellagio Hotel, the fountain there gets a Game of Thrones makeover with just two weeks until the series finale. We'll show you all of it coming up after the break. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headlines across America this morning, The New York Times is reporting that New York State Budget Deal is bringing congestion pricing plastic bag ban and a mansion tax. New York State lawmakers are approving legislation to ban plastic bags from retail stores. New York will become the second state to do so after California banned plastic bags back in 2016. Meanwhile, the state assembly is also voting in favor of a tax on multimillion dollar homes. Congestion pricing for drivers entering Midtown Manhattan, the changes are set to be enacted in 2020. A lot going on in New York.

The South Florida Sun Sentinel says that "Falling meteor lights up sky over Florida." Residents of Northern Florida experienced quite the sight Saturday night as a meteor was seen shooting across the night sky. Dash cam footage captured the rare sighting. And the National Weather Service confirmed that it was a meteor and even caught it on their forecasting map used in -- to track lighting strikes.

The Las Vegas Review-Journal reporting that Game of Thrones water show comes live on the Las Vegas strip. Pretty cool. The Bellagio fountains unveiling a new Game of Thrones inspired fountain show, complete with music and projections from the series. The show will be performed nightly at the resort until April 13th and the final season of HBO's Game of Thrones premiers on April 14th. We got a lot to talk about here.

I guess first let's tackle the New York taxes and the millionaire's tax, right ahead of, you know, Tax Day, April 15th, where New York, among other states, lost the salt. I think we could see a little sticker shock after the tax -- after Tax Day in April 15th, but this millionaire's tax --

PEEK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- is this going to continue driving people out of New York, Susan?

LI: Well, I think so. I mean we've seen an exodus of multimillionaires going to Florida, and other parts across the country where you have basically zero income taxes.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

LI: Also congestion pricing. What about average consumers that pays for rides? You know, that's going to go up per ride for, you know, the average person here in New York City as well, so, you know, they're trying to make the half billion dollar tax short fall, this is going to hurt the consumer top and bottom.

PEEK: Not to mention the price or the cost for a truck coming in and out of the city to bring in food, $133 one day. So, that's daily cost. I mean, it is going to drive up price of food and all kinds of things that are brought into the city fresh every day. I think it's unbelievable. Honestly.

BARTIROMO: It is. And Cuomo, the governor, has already said, he's facing a $2 billion hole on his budget. Governor, people are just going to continue moving out.

PEEK: Yes.

HUCKABEE: They are. I mean they might as well get a fire hose and just chase people across the bridges because that's what they're doing --

LI: That's next.

HUCKABEE: -- with their tax policies. It's amazing to me. Like this nutty thing about the plastic bag, a nickel. OK. Here's what people are missing, maybe plastic is not the best thing, but they say use recyclables. Problem with that, use a cloth bag, you go and you put meat and different produce in it, now you contaminate it, more people are getting sick because they're using these --

BARTIROMO: Oh my God.

HUCKABEE: -- sorts of bags rather than the disposable ones.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: So let's have disease. That works.

BARTIROMO: And we've said this --

LI: So early.

BARTIROMO: -- a number of times, the plastic in the ocean is not from plastic bags.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's largely nets, it's largely fishing nets.

LI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And it's not straws either.

HUCKABEE: Yes. And it's not from the U.S. largely.

PEEK: Oh, it's such tokenism. It's tokenism. You know, it's like we have to do something, but also this is a revenue grab. I mean, look, every blue state in the country is putting on these faux taxes, faux environmentally friendly taxes, whether it's straws or bags and stuff, and who does it hurt? It hurts people who can't afford it. I mean that is really the maddening thing about all of this.

BARTIROMO: They refuse to lower state taxes.

PEEK: Yes.
